abstract.objective: Identify fMRI studies of social related processing in healthy adults
inclusion_criteria: Functional MRI scan conducted while human participants performed a social-related task. Relevant constructs include (but are not limited to) Affiliation and Attachment, Social Communication, Perception and Understanding of Self, and Perception and Understanding of Others.
At least one group of healthy participants, age 17–65, even if other groups include participants with psychiatric or neurological disorders.

fulltext.objective: Identify fMRI studies of social related processing in healthy adults
inclusion_criteria: Study uses functional MRI during a social-related task. Relevant constructs include (but are not limited to)- Affiliation and Attachment, Social Communication, Perception and Understanding of Self, and Perception and Understanding of Others.
Sample- At least one group of healthy adult participants (age 17–65). Studies that also include clinical or special groups are eligible only if results for the healthy group are reported separately.

Whole-brain evidence- The paper must report at least one group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical map (e.g., main effect or within-group contrast) that is clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group and is generalizable to the healthy adult population (i.e., not limited to a narrowly defined subgroup).
It is acceptable for qualifying whole-brain results to be reported in tables of coordinates, figures, or supplementary materials, as long as they are clearly described in the text.
exclusion_criteria: Studies that report only region-of-interest (ROI) analyses with no whole-brain results.

Studies that report only seed-based connectivity, effective connectivity (e.g., PPI, DCM), or resting-state analyses (e.g., ICA, PLE, Hurst exponents) without also reporting a healthy-group whole-brain task activation map.
Studies that report only between-group contrasts or interactions (e.g., subgroup vs subgroup, patient vs control) without an accompanying unmasked, whole-brain healthy-group task effect.
Studies that include only participants outside the age range of 17–65, unless a healthy adult subgroup in this range is analyzed and reported separately.
Non-empirical papers (e.g., reviews, meta-analyses, methods-only, simulations) without original fMRI data in healthy adults.

annotations.name: social_processing_all
annotations.description: Social Processing encompasses a broad range of processes that enable individuals to perceive, interpret, and respond to social information. This includes understanding social cues, recognizing emotions in others, engaging in social interactions, and forming social bonds. Social processing is fundamental to human behavior and is crucial for effective communication and relationship-building.
inclusion_criteria: Analyses performed a social-related task. Relevant constructs include (but are not limited to) Affiliation and Attachment, Social Communication, Perception and Understanding of Self, and Perception and Understanding of Others.
The analysis/contrast must measure Social Processing

annotations.name: affiliation_attachment
annotations.description: Affiliation and Attachment is characterized by positive interactions and social bonds, and typically involves the detection of and attention to social cues, as well as social learning associated with the formation of relationships. Assessment measures generally relate to attachment styles, close relationship scales, and parental and peer bonding.
inclusion_criteria: Analyses must be on a task measuring affiliation and attachment (example tasks: Kinship-related social scenarios; Cooperation and competition; Social comparison)
The analysis/contrast must measure Affiliation and Attachment (example contrast: Loved one vs Stranger)

annotations.name: social_communication
annotations.description: Social Communication involves the exchange of socially relevant information and involves both receptive (e.g., affect recognition, facial recognition, and characterization) and productive (e.g., eye contact, expressive reciprocation, gaze following) aspects of communication. Within this construct, there exist four subconstructs: (i) Reception of Facial Communication, (ii) Production of Facial Communication, (iii) Reception of Non-Facial Communication, and (iv) Production of Non-Facial Communication.
inclusion_criteria: Analyses from tasks measuring Social Communication (example tasks: Kinship-related social scenarios; Cooperation and competition; Social comparison)
The analysis/contrast must measure Social Communication (example contrast: Loved one vs Stranger)

annotations.name: perception_self
annotations.description: Perception and Understanding of Self includes processes involved in being aware of, accessing knowledge, or making judgments about the self, and can include current cognitive or emotional internal states, traits, and/or abilities, as well as mechanisms that support self-awareness, self-monitoring, and self-knowledge. Within this construct, there exist two subconstructs: (i) Agency and (ii) Self-knowledge.
inclusion_criteria: Analyses from tasks measuring Perception and Understanding of Self (example tasks: Kinship-related social scenarios; Cooperation and competition; Social comparison)
The analysis/contrast must measure Perception and Understanding of Self (example contrast: Loved one vs Stranger)

annotations.name: perception_others
annotations.description: Perception and Understanding of Others are the representations involved in being aware of, assessing knowledge about, and reasoning about others’ emotional states, traits, or abilities. Among this construct exist three subconstructs: (i) Animacy Perception, (ii) Action Perception, and (iii) Understanding Mental States.
inclusion_criteria: Analyses from tasks measuring Perception and Understanding of Others (example tasks: Kinship-related social scenarios; Cooperation and competition; Social comparison)
The analysis/contrast must measure Perception and Understanding of Others (example contrast: Loved one vs Stranger)

studies.title: Differential response in the human amygdala to racial outgroup vs ingroup face stimuli.
studies.abstract: Here we describe response in the human amygdala to the presentation of racial outgroup vs ingroup faces. Functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) measures of brain activity were acquired while subjects who identified themselves as White or Black viewed photographs of both White and Black faces. Across all subjects, we observed significantly greater blood oxygen-level-dependent (BOLD) signal in the amygdala to outgroup vs ingroup faces, but only during later stimulus presentations. A region of interest (ROI)-based analysis of these voxels revealed a significant interaction between amygdala response to outgroup and ingroup faces over time. Specifically, the greater amygdala activation to outgroup faces during later stimulus presentations was the result of amygdala response habituation to repeated presentations of ingroup faces with sustained responses to outgroup faces. The present results suggest that amygdala responses to human face stimuli are affected by the relationship between the perceived race of the stimulus face and that of the subject. Results are discussed as consistent with a role for the amygdala in encoding socially and/or biologically relevant information. We conclude that researchers seeking to study brain responses to face stimuli in human subjects should consider the relationship between the race of subjects and stimuli as a significant potential source of variance. Moreover, these data provide a foundation for future related studies in the neuroscience of social cognition and race.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study in healthy adult participants (self-identified White and Black) performing a social perception task (viewing in-group vs out-group faces). This addresses social-related processing (perception/understanding of others) and is not a review; abstract provides sufficient info.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of social processing (perception of racial ingroup vs outgroup faces) in healthy adult participants (self-identified White and Black subjects). The paper reports group-level task-evoked BOLD differences in the amygdala to outgroup versus ingroup faces and describes voxelwise identification of those voxels followed by an ROI analysis, indicating whole-brain voxelwise effects were evaluated and reported for the healthy sample. No clinical or out-of-range-age groups dominate the reported results. Therefore it meets the review objective and inclusion criteria (social-related fMRI task; healthy adult sample; group-level univariate voxelwise/ROI-reported effects stemming from identified voxels). Confidence is somewhat reduced due to limited detail in the abstract about full tables/figures of whole-brain results, but the description indicates appropriate group-level voxelwise findings.

studies.title: When strangers pass: processing of mutual and averted social gaze in the superior temporal sulcus.
studies.abstract: Using functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI), we investigated brain activity evoked by mutual and averted gaze in a compelling and commonly experienced social encounter. Through virtual-reality goggles, subjects viewed a man who walked toward them and shifted his neutral gaze either toward (mutual gaze) or away (averted gaze) from them. Robust activity was evoked in the superior temporal sulcus (STS) and fusiform gyrus (FFG). For both conditions, STS activity was strongly right lateralized. Mutual gaze evoked greater activity in the STS than did averted gaze, whereas the FFG responded equivalently to mutual and averted gaze. Thus, we show that the STS is involved in processing social information conveyed by shifts in gaze within an overtly social context. This study extends understanding of the role of the STS in social cognition and social perception by demonstrating that it is highly sensitive to the context in which a human action occurs.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Primary fMRI study examining mutual vs. averted social gaze (social perception/communication). Not a review. Abstract does not specify participant ages or explicit confirmation of healthy adult sample, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: The study reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (n=8 in the fMRI sample) examining social gaze processing (a social-perception/communication construct). In addition to ROI analyses, the paper presents group-level, voxelwise whole-brain activation maps (across-subjects t-statistic maps displayed on a standard brain and described in the text) identifying STS and FFG activations. The healthy/control group is clearly reported separately. Although the primary analysis emphasized anatomically defined ROIs and the group voxelwise maps were produced using a fixed-effects averaging approach (limited generalizability), the manuscript nevertheless provides univariate, group-level whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps from healthy adults, satisfying the inclusion criteria for the review.

studies.title: Dehumanizing the lowest of the low: neuroimaging responses to extreme out-groups.
studies.abstract: Traditionally, prejudice has been conceptualized as simple animosity. The stereotype content model (SCM) shows that some prejudice is worse. The SCM previously demonstrated separate stereotype dimensions of warmth (low-high) and competence (low-high), identifying four distinct out-group clusters. The SCM predicts that only extreme out-groups, groups that are both stereotypically hostile and stereotypically incompetent (low warmth, low competence), such as addicts and the homeless, will be dehumanized. Prior studies show that the medial prefrontal cortex (mPFC) is necessary for social cognition. Functional magnetic resonance imaging provided data for examining brain activations in 10 participants viewing 48 photographs of social groups and 12 participants viewing objects; each picture dependably represented one SCM quadrant. Analyses revealed mPFC activation to all social groups except extreme (low-low) out-groups, who especially activated insula and amygdala, a pattern consistent with disgust, the emotion predicted by the SCM. No objects, though rated with the same emotions, activated the mPFC. This neural evidence supports the prediction that extreme out-groups may be perceived as less than human, or dehumanized.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Original fMRI study in healthy adult participants (viewing social-group photographs) examining social cognition (mPFC responses). Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI investigation of social cognition (perception/understanding of others) in healthy adult participants (Princeton undergraduates, mean age 19.5, N=10 in Study 1 and N=12 in Study 2). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate analyses (subtractive contrasts vs fixation, 3-versus-1 contrasts), with Talairach coordinates and random-effects analyses, generalizable to healthy adults. Results are not limited to ROI or connectivity-only analyses. All inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

studies.title: Distinct regions of the medial prefrontal cortex are associated with self-referential processing and perspective taking.
studies.abstract: The medial prefrontal cortex (MPFC) appears to play a prominent role in two fundamental aspects of social cognition, that is, self-referential processing and perspective taking. However, it is currently unclear whether the same or different regions of the MPFC mediate these two interdependent processes. This functional magnetic resonance imaging study sought to clarify the issue by manipulating both dimensions in a factorial design. Participants judged the extent to which trait adjectives described their own personality (e.g., "Are you sociable?") or the personality of a close friend (e.g., "Is Caroline sociable?") and were also asked to put themselves in the place of their friend (i.e., to take a third-person perspective) and estimate how this person would judge the adjectives, with the target of the judgments again being either the self (e.g., "According to Caroline, are you sociable?") or the other person (e.g., "According to Caroline, is she sociable?"). We found that self-referential processing (i.e., judgments targeting the self vs. the other person) yielded activation in the ventral and dorsal anterior MPFC, whereas perspective taking (i.e., adopting the other person's perspective, rather than one's own, when making judgments) resulted in activation in the posterior dorsal MPFC; the interaction between the two dimensions yielded activation in the left dorsal MPFC. These findings show that self-referential processing and perspective taking recruit distinct regions of the MPFC and suggest that the left dorsal MPFC may be involved in decoupling one's own from other people's perspectives on the self.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study in healthy human participants investigating self-referential processing and perspective taking (social cognition: perception/understanding of self and others). Not a review; meets task-based fMRI and population criteria based on abstract.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of social cognition (self-referential processing and perspective taking) in adults using a task manipulating self vs. other and perspective taking. The paper reports group-level task-evoked activations in medial prefrontal cortex (ventral/dorsal anterior MPFC, posterior dorsal MPFC, and left dorsal MPFC) consistent with whole-brain voxelwise contrasts rather than ROI-only results. Participants are healthy adults (typical for this JCN experimental study) and results are reported as generalizable group effects. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state, not clinical-only, and it presents univariate whole-brain task activation maps/contrasts). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

studies.title: Cerebral differences in explicit and implicit emotional processing--an fMRI study.
studies.abstract: The processing of emotional facial expression is a major part of social communication and understanding. In addition to explicit processing, facial expressions are also processed rapidly and automatically in the absence of explicit awareness. We investigated 12 healthy subjects by presenting them with an implicit and explicit emotional paradigm. The subjects reacted significantly faster in implicit than in explicit trials but did not differ in their error ratio. For the implicit condition increased signals were observed in particular in the thalami, the hippocampi, the frontal inferior gyri and the right middle temporal region. The analysis of the explicit condition showed increased blood-oxygen-level-dependent signals especially in the caudate nucleus, the cingulum and the right prefrontal cortex. The direct comparison of these 2 different processes revealed increased activity for explicit trials in the inferior, superior and middle frontal gyri, the middle cingulum and left parietal regions. Additional signal increases were detected in occipital regions, the cerebellum, and the right angular and lingual gyrus. Our data partially confirm the hypothesis of different neural substrates for the processing of implicit and explicit emotional stimuli.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study of emotional facial expression processing (social communication/perception of others) in 12 healthy human participants. Meets inclusion: task is social-related and includes healthy adults. Abstract provides sufficient detail for inclusion.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is a task-based fMRI study of emotional facial expression processing, which qualifies as social communication/social-related processing. It reports data from a group of 12 healthy subjects and describes group-level BOLD signal increases for implicit and explicit conditions and their direct comparison (listing multiple brain regions), indicating univariate whole-brain task-evoked results rather than ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses. The study therefore meets inclusion criteria: social-related task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain group-level activation maps. Uncertainty remains because the abstract does not explicitly state participant ages (17–65 requirement) and the full text/PDF was not accessible to verify exact methods (e.g., that analyses were voxelwise whole-brain and not ROI-masked). For these reasons I include the study with moderate-high confidence (0.80).

studies.title: Valuating other people's emotional face expression: a combined functional magnetic resonance imaging and electroencephalography study.
studies.abstract: Reading the facial expression of other people is a fundamental skill for social interaction. Human facial expressions of emotions are readily recognized but may also evoke the same experiential emotional state in the observer. We used event-related functional magnetic resonance imaging and multi-channel electroencephalography to determine in 14 right-handed healthy volunteers (29+/-6 years) which brain structures mediate the perception of such a shared experiential emotional state. Statistical parametric mapping showed that an area in the dorsal medial frontal cortex was specifically activated during the perception of emotions that reflected the seen happy and sad emotional face expressions. This area mapped to the pre-supplementary motor area which plays a central role in control of behavior. Low resolution brain electromagnetic tomography-based analysis of the encephalographic data revealed that the activation was detected 100 ms after face presentation onset lasting until 740 ms. Our observation substantiates recently emerging evidence suggesting that the subjective perception of an experiential emotional state-empathy-is mediated by the involvement of the dorsal medial frontal cortex.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Study used event-related fMRI during a social task (perception of others' emotional facial expressions), involved healthy adult participants (mean age 29 ±6 within 17–65), and is not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is a task-based fMRI study of social processing (perception of others' emotional facial expressions/empathy). The sample is 14 healthy adults (mean 29±6 years), within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, voxelwise statistical parametric mapping results identifying dorsal medial frontal cortex/pre-SMA activation during emotion perception, satisfying the whole-brain univariate activation requirement (not ROI-only or connectivity-only). Results are described as generalizable to the healthy group. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

studies.title: Cooperation and deception recruit different subsets of the theory-of-mind network.
studies.abstract: The term "theory of mind" (ToM) describes an evolved psychological mechanism that is necessary to represent intentions and expectations in social interaction. It is thus involved in determining the proclivity of others to cooperate or defect. While in cooperative settings between two parties the intentions and expectations of the protagonists match, they diverge in deceptive scenarios, in which one protagonist is intentionally manipulated to hold a false belief about the intention of the other. In a functional magnetic resonance imaging paradigm using cartoons showing social interactions (including the outcome of the interaction) between two or three story characters, respectively, we sought to determine those brain areas of the ToM network involved in reasoning about cooperative versus deceptive interactions. Healthy volunteers were asked to reflect upon the protagonists' intentions and expectations in cartoons depicting cooperation, deception or a combination of both, where two characters cooperated to deceive a third. Reasoning about the mental states of the story characters yielded substantial differences in activation patterns: both deception and cooperation activated bilateral temporoparietal junction, parietal and cingulate regions, while deception alone additionally recruited orbitofrontal and medial prefrontal regions. These results indicate an important role for prefrontal cortex in processing a mismatch between a character's intention and another's expectations as required in complex social interactions.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study with healthy adult volunteers performing social-cognitive tasks (theory of mind: cooperation and deception). Directly examines social processing in the brain and is not a review or meta-analysis, meeting inclusion criteria.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is a task-based fMRI study of social cognition (theory-of-mind: cooperation, deception) in healthy adults (n=13; ages 22–38). The authors report group-level, random-effects whole-brain analyses (one-sample t-test contrasting all ToM conditions vs. non-ToM and report peaks/coordinates) and provide voxelwise contrasts between conditions (reported as second-level paired t-tests and coordinate peaks). Whole-brain results are described and thresholded (p<0.02, k≥15) and anatomical coordinates are given. The sample falls within the 17–65 age range and results for the healthy group are reported separately. The paper is empirical and not limited to ROI-only, connectivity-only, or patient-only contrasts. Therefore it meets the inclusion criteria for whole-brain task-evoked activation in healthy adults.

activation_tables.table_caption: Contrasts of the ToM task conditions cooperation (COOP), deception (DEC), and cooperation/deception (COOPDEC) (n = 13; height threshold p<0.02, extent threshold k = 15).
activation_tables.table_foot: x,y,z: MNI coordinates. BA: Brodmann area. Table denotes the coordinates of local peak activation for the listed brain regions.

studies.title: Your hand or mine? The extrastriate body area.
studies.abstract: Visual images of our own and others' body parts can be highly similar, but the types of information we wish to extract from them are highly distinct. From our own body we wish to combine visual information with, at least, somatosensory, proprioceptive and motor information in order to guide our interpretation of sensory events and our actions upon the world. For others' bodies we only have visual information available, but from that we can derive much useful social information including their age, health, gender, emotional state and intentions. Consequently, a challenge for the brain is to sort visual images of our own bodies, to be integrated with processing from other sensory modalities, from highly similar images of others' bodies for social cognition. We explored the possibility that the extrastriate body area (EBA) may help to accomplish this sorting. Previous work had suggested that the EBA is responsive to images of both our own and others' body parts but does not distinguish between them. Here, using fMRI adaptation, we provide evidence that the right EBA contains separate neural sub-populations that are selectively sensitive to images of our own or others' body parts. Thus, we argue that the right EBA may perform an important sorting of body part images by identity (including self-recognition) and may interact both with brain areas involved in sensory processing and social cognition having identified our own and others' body part images respectively.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study examining neural differentiation between own vs others' body parts (self-recognition and perception of others), fitting ‘Perception and Understanding of Self’ and ‘Perception and Understanding of Others’. Uses functional MRI in human adult participants; not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: The study is an original task-based fMRI investigation in healthy adult participants examining perception/understanding of self versus others (own vs. others' body parts), which fits the review’s social-related constructs. Sample consists of healthy adults (n=12–15 per experiment). The paper reports group-level univariate whole-brain contrasts used for ROI localization (e.g., body minus objects localizer; coordinates and voxel counts for EBA, V1/2, LOC are provided and thresholding is described), satisfying the requirement for whole-brain task-evoked results in the healthy group. Although key adaptation analyses are conducted within subject-specific ROIs, the manuscript includes whole-brain contrast results (tables/coordinates) and is not ROI-only or connectivity-only. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

studies.title: Listening to humans walking together activates the social brain circuitry.
studies.abstract: Human footsteps carry a vast amount of social information, which is often unconsciously noted. Using functional magnetic resonance imaging, we analyzed brain networks activated by footstep sounds of one or two persons walking. Listening to two persons walking together activated brain areas previously associated with affective states and social interaction, such as the subcallosal gyrus bilaterally, the right temporal pole, and the right amygdala. These areas seem to be involved in the analysis of persons' identity and complex social stimuli on the basis of auditory cues. Single footsteps activated only the biological motion area in the posterior STS region. Thus, hearing two persons walking together involved a more widespread brain network than did hearing footsteps from a single person.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study examining neural responses to auditory social cues (one vs two people walking), addressing social perception/understanding of others. Abstract does not report participant ages/health status; include for full-text review to confirm participants are healthy adults (17–65) and meet eligibility.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an empirical fMRI study using a social-related auditory task (perception/understanding of others: distinguishing one vs two walkers). Sample comprises 12 healthy adults aged 22–37 (within 17–65). The authors report group-level, random-effects, whole-brain univariate analyses (GLM) with voxelwise contrasts (e.g., STEP1+STEP2 – REST; STEP1 – NOISE1; STEP2 – NOISE2), including statistical maps, Talairach coordinates, and figures. Analyses are not limited to ROIs or connectivity and results are clearly reported for the healthy/control group. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

studies.title: What's in a smile? Neural correlates of facial embodiment during social interaction.
studies.abstract: Previous investigations have shown that the perception of socially relevant facial expressions, indicating someone else's intention to communicate (e.g., smiling), correlate with increased activity in zygomaticus major muscle regardless of whether the facial expressions seen are directed towards the human observer or toward someone else (Mojzisch et al., 2006). These spontaneous, involuntary reactions have been described as facial mimicry and seem to be of considerable importance for successful interpersonal communication. We investigated whether specific neural substrates underlie these responses by performing a finite impulse response (FIR) analysis of an experiment using functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) to investigate the perception of socially relevant facial expressions (Schilbach et al., 2006). This analysis demonstrates that differential neural activity can be detected relative to the FIR time window in which facial mimicry occurs. The neural network found includes but extends beyond classical motor regions (face motor area) recruiting brain regions known to be involved in social cognition. This network is proposed to subserve the integration of emotional and action-related processes as part of a pre-reflective, embodied reaction to the perception of socially relevant facial expressions as well as a reflective representation of self and other.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Original fMRI experiment on perception of socially relevant facial expressions/social interaction (facial mimicry) recruiting social cognition networks. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract does not state participant ages but implies healthy human subjects; include for full-text to confirm demographics and eligibility.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an event-related fMRI study reanalyzed with FIR focusing on perception of socially relevant facial expressions (social communication/perception of others). Participants: 17 healthy right-handed adult males (mean age 25.9), within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise univariate analyses (random-effects ANOVA; SPM; threshold p=.001 uncorrected; coordinates and activation tables/figures provided for main effects and time-bin contrasts). It is not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, and reports healthy-group task-evoked whole-brain activation maps generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

studies.title: Observing social interactions: the effect of gaze.
studies.abstract: Our social abilities depend on specialized brain systems that allow us to perform crucial operations such as interpreting the actions of others. This functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) study investigated whether human brain activity evoked by the observation of social interactions is modulated by gaze. During scanning participants observed social or individual actions performed by agents whose gaze could be either available or masked. Results demonstrated that the observation of social interactions evoked activity within a dorsal sector of the medial prefrontal cortex (MPFC), an area classically involved in social cognition. Importantly, activity within this area was modulated by whether the gaze of the agents performing the observed action was or was not available. The implications of these findings for a role played by the dorsal medial prefrontal cortex (dMPFC) in terms of inferential processes concerned with social interactions are considered.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study where participants observed social interactions; investigates social cognition (dMPFC) and modulation by gaze. Involves human participants performing a social-related task; no indication of clinical populations. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=17, mean age 26, range within 17–65). The task investigates social cognition (observation of social vs. individual actions and effects of gaze), which falls squarely within social-related processing. The paper reports group-level, random-effects whole-brain univariate analyses (main effects and interaction), with SPM results, coordinate tables, and statistical maps (p<.001 uncorrected) clearly described for the healthy participant group. No ROI-only, connectivity-only, or non-healthy-only limitations apply. All inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated, so the study should be included.

studies.title: Dynamic pupillary exchange engages brain regions encoding social salience.
studies.abstract: Covert exchange of autonomic responses may shape social affective behavior, as observed in mirroring of pupillary responses during sadness processing. We examined how, independent of facial emotional expression, dynamic coherence between one's own and another's pupil size modulates regional brain activity. Fourteen subjects viewed pairs of eye stimuli while undergoing fMRI. Using continuous pupillometry biofeedback, the size of the observed pupils was varied, correlating positively or negatively with changes in participants' own pupils. Viewing both static and dynamic stimuli activated right fusiform gyrus. Observing dynamically changing pupils activated STS and amygdala, regions engaged by non-static and salient facial features. Discordance between observed and observer's pupillary changes enhanced activity within bilateral anterior insula, left amygdala and anterior cingulate. In contrast, processing positively correlated pupils enhanced activity within left frontal operculum. Our findings suggest pupillary signals are monitored continuously during social interactions and that incongruent changes activate brain regions involved in tracking motivational salience and attentionally meaningful information. Naturalistically, dynamic coherence in pupillary change follows fluctuations in ambient light. Correspondingly, in social contexts discordant pupil response is likely to reflect divergence of dispositional state. Our data provide empirical evidence for an autonomically mediated extension of forward models of motor control into social interaction.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Task involves fMRI in healthy human participants (N=14) performing a social-related task (perception of others’ pupillary responses/social salience). Not a review; meets inclusion criteria for social processing in healthy adults.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=14, mean age 22) examining social-related processing (perception of others’ pupillary responses and their social salience). The study reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects univariate analyses (main effects of viewing eye stimuli reported at whole-brain corrected thresholds and effects of pupil change reported with cluster thresholds), and presents voxelwise activations (including tables/coordinates and figures). The task is social/perceptual and maps are generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state, healthy adult group reported separately).

studies.title: Amygdala activity to fear and anger in healthy young males is associated with testosterone.
studies.abstract: Neuroimaging studies have documented modulation of the activity of the amygdala - a key node in the neural network underlying emotion perception and processing, and one that has also been associated with regulating aggression - by exogenous testosterone. However, results on the impact of normal range testosterone levels on explicit emotion recognition as a prerequisite for social interaction and amygdala activation in healthy young males are missing. Hence, we performed functional MRI at 3T in a group of 21 healthy males during explicit emotion recognition with a protocol specifically optimized to reliably detect amygdala activation. We observed similar amygdala activation to all emotions presented without any effect of gender of poser or laterality. Reaction times to fearful male faces were found negatively correlated to testosterone concentration, while no significant effects emerged for other emotions and neutral expressions. Correlation analyses revealed a significant positive association between testosterone levels and amygdala response to fearful and angry facial expressions, but not to other expressions. Hence, our results demonstrate that testosterone levels affect amygdala activation and also behavioral responses particularly to threat-related emotions in healthy young males. We conclude that these findings add to our understanding of emotion processing and its modulation by neuroendocrine factors.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Study used 3T fMRI while 21 healthy young males performed explicit emotion recognition — a social perception/understanding task. Participants are healthy adults within 17–65. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text review.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an empirical fMRI study of social processing (explicit emotion recognition of facial expressions) in healthy adult males (age 21–33). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain (‘‘whole-slab’’) analyses and activation maps (e.g., Figure 2) and provides cluster coordinates/ANOVA results from whole-brain analyses (parahippocampal gyrus; inferior frontal gyrus coordinates reported). Although ROI analyses are also performed for the amygdala, whole-brain task-evoked results for the healthy sample are clearly reported and generalizable to healthy adults. All inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

studies.title: Neural correlates of direct and reflected self-appraisals in adolescents and adults: when social perspective-taking informs self-perception.
studies.abstract: Classic theories of self-development suggest people define themselves in part through internalized perceptions of other people's beliefs about them, known as reflected self-appraisals. This study uses functional magnetic resonance imaging to compare the neural correlates of direct and reflected self-appraisals in adolescence (N = 12, ages 11-14 years) and adulthood (N = 12, ages 23-30 years). During direct self-reflection, adolescents demonstrated greater activity than adults in networks relevant to self-perception (medial prefrontal and parietal cortices) and social-cognition (dorsomedial prefrontal cortex, temporal-parietal junction, and posterior superior temporal sulcus), suggesting adolescent self-construals may rely more heavily on others' perspectives about the self. Activity in the medial fronto-parietal network was also enhanced when adolescents took the perspective of someone more relevant to a given domain.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Study used fMRI during social-related tasks (direct and reflected self-appraisals — perception/understanding of self). Includes a healthy adult group (ages 23–30) within 17–65. Not a review or meta-analysis.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: The study uses task-based fMRI probing self- and social-cognitive processes (direct and reflected self-appraisals). It includes a healthy adult group (N=12, ages 22.6–30.4) reported separately from adolescents. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, unmasked voxelwise analyses (one-sample t-tests and conjunctions for each appraisal condition in adults vs rest; interaction and between-group whole-brain contrasts) with coordinates and figures, corrected for multiple comparisons—fulfilling the whole-brain evidence requirement. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity/resting-only, includes healthy adults within 17–65). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

studies.title: Common premotor regions for the perception and production of prosody and correlations with empathy and prosodic ability.
studies.abstract: Prosody, the melody and intonation of speech, involves the rhythm, rate, pitch and voice quality to relay linguistic and emotional information from one individual to another. A significant component of human social communication depends upon interpreting and responding to another person's prosodic tone as well as one's own ability to produce prosodic speech. However there has been little work on whether the perception and production of prosody share common neural processes, and if so, how these might correlate with individual differences in social ability.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study investigating perception and production of prosody (a social-communication process) and correlations with empathy/prosodic ability. This addresses social-related processing in humans and is an original fMRI research article rather than a review. Although the abstract does not explicitly state participant ages/health, the study likely involved healthy adult participants; include for full-text confirmation if needed.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an empirical fMRI study of social communication (prosody perception/production and empathy) in healthy adults (n=19; age 18–58). Group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts are reported (e.g., “happy–neutral”, “question–neutral”) using random-effects analyses with FDR correction and cluster reporting; results and coordinates are described in the text and supplementary materials. The paper does not rely solely on ROI or connectivity analyses, and reports healthy-group task activation maps generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria apply. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

studies.title: Mapping the information flow from one brain to another during gestural communication.
studies.abstract: Both the putative mirror neuron system (pMNS) and the ventral medial prefrontal cortex (vmPFC) are deemed important for social interaction: the pMNS because it supposedly "resonates" with the actions of others, the vmPFC because it is involved in mentalizing. Strictly speaking, the resonance property of the pMNS has never been investigated. Classical functional MRI experiments have only investigated whether pMNS regions augment their activity when an action is seen or executed. Resonance, however, entails more than only "going on and off together". Activity in the pMNS of an observer should continuously follow the more subtle changes over time in activity of the pMNS of the actor. Here we directly explore whether such resonance indeed occurs during continuous streams of actions. We let participants play the game of charades while we measured brain activity of both gesturer and guesser. We then applied a method to localize directed influences between the brains of the participants: between-brain Granger-causality mapping. Results show that a guesser's brain activity in regions involved in mentalizing and mirroring echoes the temporal structure of a gesturer's brain activity. This provides evidence for resonance theories and indicates a fine-grained temporal interplay between regions involved in motor planning and regions involved in thinking about the mental states of others. Furthermore, this method enables experiments to be more ecologically valid by providing the opportunity to leave social interaction unconstrained. This, in turn, would allow us to tap into the neural substrates of social deficits such as autism spectrum disorder.
studies.journal: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study that measured brain activity of both gesturer and guesser during charades (social communication). Investigates mirroring and mentalizing—clearly social-related processing—in what are presumably healthy adult participants. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info to meet inclusion criteria.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an empirical fMRI study of gestural social communication (charades) in healthy adult participants (18 analyzed; mean age 27.5), meeting the sample criterion (ages within 17–65). The experiment used task-based fMRI during a social communication task. The paper reports group-level whole-brain analyses (GLM-derived activations used to define mirror ROIs, references to GLM results and figures/SI showing clusters), and presents univariate results in the main text and supplementary figures/tables. Although the manuscript emphasizes between-brain Granger-causality mapping, it also includes traditional GLM whole-brain analyses (and seed ROI definitions based on these), so it is not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only reporting. Therefore all inclusion criteria are satisfied and no exclusion criteria are violated.

studies.title: Clan mentality: evidence that the medial prefrontal cortex responds to close others.
studies.abstract: Kinship, friendship alliances, and perceptions of others' beliefs guide social interactions and are central to cohesive group behavior. Under certain conditions, brain systems that involve regions along the frontal midline increase activity when inferences are drawn about others who share a similar view to one's own (similarity). A prominent hypothesis is that these regions contribute to social cognition by simulating the other person's perspective based on one's own experience. An alternative is that certain regions process the social relevance of the person (closeness) to oneself and contribute to the assessment akin to signals that govern behavioral approach responses. These alternatives were explored across four functional magnetic resonance imaging experiments (n = 98). Experiment 1 localized the target midline regions in the rostral anterior cingulate cortex and anterior medial prefrontal cortex by having participants make personal judgments. The two dimensions (similarity, closeness) were crossed in experiment 2 using actual friends of the participant and unknown others. Making judgments about oneself and friends resulted in increased midline response relative to unknown others regardless of whether the friends shared similar views as the participant. Experiment 3 revealed that similarity was not a factor even when close others were not included. Experiment 4 directly contrasted two extremes: participants made inferences about similar, unknown others and dissimilar friends. Judgments about the close others again increased blood oxygenation level-dependent response along the frontal midline. These results encourage further exploration of the idea that frontal systems linked with limbic circuits facilitate assessment of the relevance or personal significance in social contexts.
studies.journal: The Journal of neuroscience : the official journal of the Society for Neuroscience
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Study reports fMRI experiments (n=98) in healthy adults performing social-cognitive tasks about self, friends, and others (closeness/similarity), directly addressing social-related processing. Not a review or meta-analysis and meets age/participant criteria based on abstract.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of social cognition in healthy adults (n=98, mean age 20.7) using social-related tasks (self/close others/strangers attribute and preference judgments), matching the review constructs (perception/understanding of self and others). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts (e.g., self > Bush; friends > strangers) with voxelwise maps and thresholding (p<0.001) presented in figures and described in the text. Results for the healthy participants are reported and generalizable to healthy adults. The study includes both whole-brain analyses and ROI follow-ups, so it does not meet any exclusion criteria (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not non-empirical). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and none of the exclusion criteria.

studies.title: Individuating faces and common objects produces equal responses in putative face-processing areas in the ventral occipitotemporal cortex.
studies.abstract: Controversy surrounds the proposal that specific human cortical regions in the ventral occipitotemporal cortex, commonly called the fusiform face area (FFA) and occipital face area (OFA), are specialized for face processing. Here, we present findings from an fMRI study of identity discrimination of faces and objects that demonstrates the FFA and OFA are equally responsive to processing stimuli at the level of individuals (i.e., individuation), be they human faces or non-face objects. The FFA and OFA were defined via a passive viewing task as regions that produced greater activation to faces relative to non-face stimuli within the middle fusiform gyrus and inferior occipital gyrus. In the individuation task, participants judged whether sequentially presented images of faces, diverse objects, or wristwatches depicted the identical or a different exemplar. All three stimulus types produced equivalent BOLD activation within the FFA and OFA; that is, there was no face-specific or face-preferential processing. Critically, individuation processing did not eliminate an object superiority effect relative to faces within a region more closely linked to object processing in the lateral occipital complex (LOC), suggesting that individuation processes are reasonably specific to the FFA and OFA. Taken together, these findings challenge the prevailing view that the FFA and OFA are face-specific processing regions, demonstrating instead that they function to individuate - i.e., identify specific individuals - within a category. These findings have significant implications for understanding the function of brain regions widely believed to play an important role in social cognition.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: The fMRI task is identity discrimination of faces, which falls under Perception and Understanding of Others (a social-related construct). No exclusion criteria apply. Abstract does not specify participant ages/health status, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility (healthy adults age 17–65).
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This fMRI study investigates face individuation, which falls under social-related processing (Perception and Understanding of Others). Sample comprises healthy adults (final N=15, mean age 24.8), within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task analyses for the individuation task (repeated-measures ANOVA across participants with voxelwise thresholds and cluster correction), with whole-brain contrasts and reported regional activations; thus whole-brain, task-evoked maps for the healthy group are available. The study also includes ROI analyses but is not limited to them. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

studies.title: Recruitment of both the mirror and the mentalizing networks when observing social interactions depicted by point-lights: a neuroimaging study.
studies.abstract: Understanding social interactions requires the ability to accurately interpret conspecifics' actions, sometimes only on the basis of subtle body language analysis. Here we address an important issue that has not yet received much attention in social neuroscience, that of an interaction between two agents. We attempted to isolate brain responses to two individuals interacting compared to two individuals acting independently.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Abstract describes a neuroimaging study investigating brain responses to observed social interactions (mirror and mentalizing networks), meeting the review’s focus on social processing. While the abstract does not explicitly state ‘fMRI’ or participant ages, it likely involves functional neuroimaging in healthy adults; because information is incomplete, include for full-text review to confirm methods and sample.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of social processing (observing social interactions vs non-social movements) in healthy adults (N=14, mean age 29.4). It reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task activation contrasts (SI > NSI) using random-effects one-sample t-tests with FDR correction (p<0.05) and lists activated clusters/locations. The task probes social perception/understanding of others via point-light displays. It is not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and presents univariate whole-brain results generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

The activations presented survived to correction for multiple comparisons (FDR) across the whole brain at p<0.05. Only activations in excess of 10 voxels are listed. L/R: left and right hemispheres.

The activations presented survived to correction for multiple comparisons (FDR) across the whole brain at p<0.05. Only activations in excess of 10 voxels are listed. L/R: left and right hemispheres.

studies.title: Functional dissociation of the left and right fusiform gyrus in self-face recognition.
studies.abstract: It is well known that the fusiform gyrus is engaged in face perception, such as the processes of face familiarity and identity. However, the functional role of the fusiform gyrus in face processing related to high-level social cognition remains unclear. The current study assessed the functional role of individually defined fusiform face area (FFA) in the processing of self-face physical properties and self-face identity. We used functional magnetic resonance imaging to monitor neural responses to rapidly presented face stimuli drawn from morph continua between self-face (Morph 100%) and a gender-matched friend's face (Morph 0%) in a face recognition task. Contrasting Morph 100% versus Morph 60% that differed in self-face physical properties but were both recognized as the self uncovered neural activity sensitive to self-face physical properties in the left FFA. Contrasting Morphs 50% that were recognized as the self versus a friend on different trials revealed neural modulations associated with self-face identity in the right FFA. Moreover, the right FFA activity correlated with the frequency of recognizing Morphs 50% as the self. Our results provide evidence for functional dissociations of the left and right FFAs in the representations of self-face physical properties and self-face identity.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study examining self-face recognition, which maps onto 'Perception and Understanding of Self' — a social-related construct. Appears to involve healthy adult participants (not reported explicitly), and is not a review. Because participant ages/clinical status are not specified in the abstract, include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of self-face recognition (Perception and Understanding of Self), a social-related construct. Sample: healthy adult participants (N=16 analyzed; ages 19–24) within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, random-effects, univariate whole-brain analyses (e.g., contrasts for Morph 50% recognized as self vs friend) with voxelwise thresholds and cluster-level family-wise error correction; coordinates and activated clusters (MPFC, PCC, precuneus) are reported. Thus it provides whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps generalizable to healthy adults. It is empirical, not ROI-only, and does not violate exclusion criteria. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

studies.title: Brain imaging investigation of the neural correlates of observing virtual social interactions.
studies.abstract: The ability to gauge social interactions is crucial in the assessment of others' intentions. Factors such as facial expressions and body language affect our decisions in personal and professional life alike (1). These "friend or foe" judgements are often based on first impressions, which in turn may affect our decisions to "approach or avoid". Previous studies investigating the neural correlates of social cognition tended to use static facial stimuli (2). Here, we illustrate an experimental design in which whole-body animated characters were used in conjunction with functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) recordings. Fifteen participants were presented with short movie-clips of guest-host interactions in a business setting, while fMRI data were recorded; at the end of each movie, participants also provided ratings of the host behaviour. This design mimics more closely real-life situations, and hence may contribute to better understanding of the neural mechanisms of social interactions in healthy behaviour, and to gaining insight into possible causes of deficits in social behaviour in such clinical conditions as social anxiety and autism (3).
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI was used while healthy adult participants (n=15) viewed and rated short movie clips of social (guest-host) interactions, addressing neural correlates of social cognition. This matches the review objective and inclusion criteria; the study is not a review/meta-analysis.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: The study uses task-based fMRI of social processing (observing virtual social interactions). Participants are healthy adults (protocol describes recruitment by age/health and Figure 1 notes group data from 15 participants). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain task-evoked activation maps/contrasts (social interaction vs. control) with activations in STS, mPFC, and amygdala — i.e., univariate whole-brain results generalizable to the healthy group. It is not ROI-only, connectivity-only, nor non-empirical. No exclusion criteria are met. Therefore the study satisfies all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

studies.title: Differential brain responses to social exclusion by one's own versus opposite-gender peers.
studies.abstract: Human peer relations provide tangible benefits, including food and protection, as well as emotional benefits. While social exclusion poses a threat to all of these benefits, the psychological threat is particularly susceptible to modulation by the relation of the excluders to the excluded person. The current study used functional magnetic resonance imaging to explore the effects of manipulating the gender relation of participants to their excluders during an interactive ball-toss game. Ventral anterior cingulate cortex activation was higher during exclusion by same-gender peers, while right ventrolateral prefrontal cortex activation negatively correlated with self-reported distress in other-gender exclusion. Results imply that exclusion by one's own gender is fundamentally different from exclusion by the opposite gender, and suggest a regulatory role for ventrolateral prefrontal cortex in response to out-group exclusion. Individual differences in implicit gender attitudes modulated neural responses to exclusion. The importance of these findings to investigations of social cognition is discussed.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study using an interactive social exclusion task (ball-toss game) in human participants, examining neural responses to social relationships (same- vs opposite-gender). Appears to involve healthy adult participants and directly addresses social processing. Not a review or meta-analysis.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an empirical task-based fMRI study (Cyberball) probing social exclusion—clearly a social-related construct (affiliation/belonging). Sample consists of healthy adults (n=20 analyzed; ages ~25), within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (e.g., social exclusion > fair play; same- vs other-gender exclusion) with cluster-corrected thresholds and tables/figures of coordinates. Results are reported for the healthy/control sample and are not limited to ROI-only, connectivity-only, or between-group-only contrasts. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

studies.title: Predicting decisions in human social interactions using real-time fMRI and pattern classification.
studies.abstract: Negotiation and trade typically require a mutual interaction while simultaneously resting in uncertainty which decision the partner ultimately will make at the end of the process. Assessing already during the negotiation in which direction one's counterpart tends would provide a tremendous advantage. Recently, neuroimaging techniques combined with multivariate pattern classification of the acquired data have made it possible to discriminate subjective states of mind on the basis of their neuronal activation signature. However, to enable an online-assessment of the participant's mind state both approaches need to be extended to a real-time technique. By combining real-time functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) and online pattern classification techniques, we show that it is possible to predict human behavior during social interaction before the interacting partner communicates a specific decision. Average accuracy reached approximately 70% when we predicted online the decisions of volunteers playing the ultimatum game, a well-known paradigm in economic game theory. Our results demonstrate the successful online analysis of complex emotional and cognitive states using real-time fMRI, which will enable a major breakthrough for social fMRI by providing information about mental states of partners already during the mutual interaction. Interestingly, an additional whole brain classification across subjects confirmed the online results: anterior insula, ventral striatum, and lateral orbitofrontal cortex, known to act in emotional self-regulation and reward processing for adjustment of behavior, appeared to be strong determinants of later overt behavior in the ultimatum game. Using whole brain classification we were also able to discriminate between brain processes related to subjective emotional and motivational states and brain processes related to the evaluation of objective financial incentives.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Study uses real-time fMRI while volunteers played the ultimatum game, a social interaction/decision-making task. It reports neural correlates of social decision behavior in human participants (not a review). Participant health appears to be healthy volunteers; fits inclusion criteria for social fMRI in adults.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of social decision-making (ultimatum game) in healthy adult participants (male, age 23–28). The paper reports whole-brain offline analyses: cross-subject whole-brain classification, extraction of discriminating volumes mapped back into voxel space, and voxelwise significance testing (permutation-based p-values, reported discriminating volumes and anatomical loci). Results are presented at the group level and generalize across subjects (leave-one-subject-out cross-subject model). Thus it meets: (1) social-related fMRI task, (2) healthy adult sample within age range, and (3) group-level whole-brain voxelwise results (discriminating volumes with voxelwise p-values and reported regions). No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study should be INCLUDED.

studies.title: The neural correlates of emotional prosody comprehension: disentangling simple from complex emotion.
studies.abstract: Emotional prosody comprehension (EPC), the ability to interpret another person's feelings by listening to their tone of voice, is crucial for effective social communication. Previous studies assessing the neural correlates of EPC have found inconsistent results, particularly regarding the involvement of the medial prefrontal cortex (mPFC). It remained unclear whether the involvement of the mPFC is linked to an increased demand in socio-cognitive components of EPC such as mental state attribution and if basic perceptual processing of EPC can be performed without the contribution of this region.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: The abstract addresses neural correlates of emotional prosody comprehension, a social-communication task relevant to the review, but does not specify that fMRI was used or detail participant health/ages. Insufficient methodological/sample information to confirm inclusion criteria, so include for full-text review to verify imaging modality and healthy adult sample.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of emotional prosody comprehension that specifically contrasts complex (including social emotions: proud, guilty) versus simple emotions, addressing social-related processing (perception/understanding of others). Sample comprises healthy adult participants (n=19 males, age 18–51), within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked contrasts (emotional vs neutral; complex vs simple), analyzed in SPM8 with corrected cluster-wise inference and reported activations, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. It is not an ROI-only, connectivity-only, between-group-only, or non-empirical paper. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

studies.title: Seeing is believing: neural mechanisms of action-perception are biased by team membership.
studies.abstract: Group identification can lead to a biased view of the world in favor of "in-group" members. Studying the brain processes that underlie such in-group biases is important for a wider understanding of the potential influence of social factors on basic perceptual processes. In this study, we used functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) to investigate how people perceive the actions of in-group and out-group members, and how their biased view in favor of own team members manifests itself in the brain. We divided participants into two teams and had them judge the relative speeds of hand actions performed by an in-group and an out-group member in a competitive situation. Participants judged hand actions performed by in-group members as being faster than those of out-group members, even when the two actions were performed at physically identical speeds. In an additional fMRI experiment, we showed that, contrary to common belief, such skewed impressions arise from a subtle bias in perception and associated brain activity rather than decision-making processes, and that this bias develops rapidly and involuntarily as a consequence of group affiliation. Our findings suggest that the neural mechanisms that underlie human perception are shaped by social context.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study examining perception of in-group vs out-group actions (social perception/understanding of others), consistent with review objective. Involves human participants and task during fMRI; not a review. Abstract does not state participant ages or explicitly state health status, so include for full-text verification.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (right-handed Caucasian males, ages 17–43) using a social task manipulating minimal in-group vs out-group membership and action perception. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (e.g., action videos vs fixation; own-team vs other-team; decision vs press) with voxelwise thresholds and cluster-level FWE correction, and provides peak coordinates and cluster statistics. Results for the healthy/control sample are reported and generalizable to healthy adults. It does not rely solely on ROI, connectivity, or between-group-only contrasts. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

studies.title: Neuroimaging self-esteem: a fMRI study of individual differences in women.
studies.abstract: Although neuroimaging studies strongly implicate the medial prefrontal cortex (ventral and dorsal), cingulate gyrus (anterior and posterior), precuneus and temporoparietal cortex in mediating self-referential processing (SRP), little is known about the neural bases mediating individual differences in valenced SRP, that is, processes intrinsic to self-esteem. This study investigated the neural correlates of experimentally engendered valenced SRP via the Visual-Verbal Self-Other Referential Processing Task in 20 women with fMRI. Participants viewed pictures of themselves or unknown other women during separate trials while covertly rehearsing 'I am' or 'She is', followed by reading valenced trait adjectives, thus variably associating the self/other with positivity/negativity. Response within dorsal and ventral medial prefrontal cortex, cingulate cortex and left temporoparietal cortex varied with individual differences in both pre-task rated self-descriptiveness of the words, as well as task-induced affective responses. Results are discussed as they relate to a social cognitive and affective neuroscience view of self-esteem.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Primary fMRI study investigating valenced self-referential (social) processing using a self/other task in 20 healthy adult women. Fits inclusion: functional MRI during a social-related task (perception/understanding of self), healthy adult sample within target age range. Not a review.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of healthy adult participants (20 women, ages 18–52) using a social cognition task probing self- and other-referential processing (valenced SRP/ORP), which falls squarely under ‘Perception and Understanding of Self/Other’. The paper reports whole-brain, group-level univariate task contrasts (e.g., S-N vs baseline, S-P vs baseline, and planned contrasts S-N vs S-P, S-N vs O-N, S-P vs O-P) analyzed with SPM8 and provides voxelwise maps, cluster results and coordinates (voxel-wise P<0.005 with cluster thresholds, tables/figures). Results are presented for the healthy sample without restriction to a narrow subgroup. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not connectivity/resting-only, and participants are within 17–65). Therefore the study meets all inclusion requirements for the meta-analysis.

studies.title: Age-related changes to the neural correlates of social evaluation.
studies.abstract: Recent work suggests the existence of a specialized neural system underlying social processing that may be relatively spared with age, unlike pervasive aging-related decline occurring in many cognitive domains. We investigated how neural mechanisms underlying social evaluation are engaged with age, and how age-related changes to socioemotional goals affect recruitment of regions within this network. In a functional MRI study, 15 young and 15 older adults formed behavior-based impressions of individuals. They also responded to a prompt that was interpersonally meaningful, social but interpersonally irrelevant, or non-social. Both age groups engaged regions implicated in mentalizing and impression formation when making social relative to non-social evaluations, including dorsal and ventral medial prefrontal cortices, precuneus, and temporoparietal junction. Older adults had increased activation over young in right temporal pole when making social relative to non-social evaluations, suggesting reliance on past experiences when evaluating others. Young adults had greater activation than old in posterior cingulate gyrus when making interpersonally irrelevant, compared to interpersonally meaningful, evaluations, potentially reflecting enhanced valuation of this information. The findings demonstrate the age-related preservation of the neural correlates underlying social evaluation, and suggest that functioning in these regions might be mediated by age-related changes in socioemotional goals.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study of social evaluation/impression formation in healthy young and older adults, addressing social processing. Abstract does not specify participant ages (17–65 criterion unclear), so include for full-text review to confirm ages and eligibility.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an empirical task-based fMRI study of social evaluation (impression formation), addressing social cognition constructs (perception/understanding of others). It reports group-level, whole-brain univariate contrasts (social vs non-social; social-meaningful vs social-irrelevant), conjunction analyses, corrected cluster results, and ROI percent-signal-change characterization — not ROI-only or connectivity-only. The sample includes a healthy young adult group (ages 20–29) within the 17–65 range and reports separate group-level results for age groups, so acceptable despite also including an older (>65) group. Therefore it meets the inclusion criteria for whole-brain task activation in healthy adults and should be INCLUDED.

studies.title: The neural bases of social intention understanding: the role of interaction goals.
studies.abstract: Decoding others' intentions is a crucial aspect of social cognition. Neuroimaging studies suggest that inferring immediate goals engages the neural system for action understanding (i.e. mirror system), while the decoding of long-term intentions requires the system subserving the attribution of mental states (i.e. mentalizing). A controversial issue, stimulated by recent inconsistent results, concerns whether the two systems are concurrently vs. exclusively involved in intention understanding. This issue is particularly relevant in the case of social interactions, whose processing has been mostly, but not uncontroversially, associated with the mentalizing system. We tested the alternative hypothesis that the relative contribution of the two systems in intention understanding may also depend on the shared goal of interacting agents. To this purpose, 27 participants observed social interactions differing in their cooperative vs. affective shared goal during functional-Magnetic-Resonance-Imaging. The processing of both types of interactions activated the right temporo-parietal junction involved in mentalizing on action goals. Additionally, whole-brain and regions-of-interest analyses showed that the action understanding system (inferior prefrontal-parietal cortex) was more strongly activated by cooperative interactions, while the mentalizing-proper system (medial prefrontal cortex) was more strongly engaged by affective interactions. These differences were modulated by individual differences in empathizing. Both systems can thus be involved in understanding social intentions, with a relative weighting depending on the specific shared goal of the interaction.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Primary research fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=27) examining social intention understanding during observation of social interactions; task clearly addresses social cognition (perception/understanding of others). Not a review/meta-analysis and meets inclusion criteria. Age range not specified but sample described as participants (likely adults); sufficient evidence from abstract to include for full-text data extraction.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of social cognition (understanding social intentions/cooperative vs. affective interactions) in healthy adult participants (N=27; ages ~24–26), within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked analyses (random-effects, full-factorial second-level analyses) with whole-brain statistical maps and FWE-corrected results, plus coordinate tables and conjunction/contrast maps; results are not limited to ROI-only or connectivity analyses. Healthy-group results are clearly reported and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-empirical, or out-of-range sample) are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.
