studies.title: Neural oscillations in human auditory cortex revealed by fast fMRI during auditory perception.
studies.abstract: Previous work pointed to the neural and functional significance of infraslow neural oscillations below 1 ​Hz that can be detected and precisely located with fast functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI). While previous work demonstrated this significance for brain dynamics during very low-level sensory stimulation, we here provide the first evidence for the detectability and functional significance of infraslow oscillatory blood oxygenation level-dependent (BOLD) responses to auditory stimulation by the sociobiological relevant and more complex category of voices. Previous work pointed to a specific area of the mammalian auditory cortex (AC) that is sensitive to vocal signals as quantified by activation levels. Here we show, by using fast fMRI, that the human voice-sensitive AC prioritizes vocal signals not only in terms of activity level but also in terms of specific infraslow BOLD oscillations. We found unique sustained and transient oscillatory BOLD patterns in the AC for vocal signals. For transient oscillatory patterns, vocal signals showed faster peak oscillatory responses across all AC regions. Furthermore, we identified an exclusive sustained oscillatory component for vocal signals in the primary AC. Fast fMRI thus demonstrates the significance and richness of infraslow BOLD oscillations for neurocognitive mechanisms in social cognition as demonstrated here for the sociobiological relevance of voice processing.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Fast fMRI study examines voice processing and explicitly frames findings in social cognition (voice-sensitive auditory cortex), fitting social communication/perception constructs. Abstract does not report participant characteristics or ages (healthy adults 17–65), so inclusion cannot be confirmed from abstract alone — include for full-text review to verify sample criteria.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is a task-based fMRI study in healthy adult participants (Experiment 1: N=13, ages 21–41; Experiment 2: N=18, ages 18–33), testing processing of vocal versus non-vocal sounds (socially relevant stimuli). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain activation maps and contrasts (vocal > non-vocal and vice versa) with thresholding (FDR-corrected) and presents univariate task-evoked results generalizable to healthy adults. The task involves social-related processing (voice perception/communication). No exclusion criteria are triggered (not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and healthy adult group results are reported). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

studies.title: Intact neural representations of affective meaning of touch but lack of embodied resonance in autism: a multi-voxel pattern analysis study.
studies.abstract: Humans can easily grasp the affective meaning of touch when observing social interactions. Several neural systems support this ability, including the theory of mind (ToM) network and the somatosensory system linked to embodied resonance, but it is unclear how these systems are affected in autism spectrum disorder (ASD). Individuals with ASD exhibit impairments in the use of nonverbal communication such as social and reciprocal touch. Despite the importance of touch in social communication and the reported touch aversion in ASD, surprisingly little is known about the neural systems underlying impairments in touch communication in ASD.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI MVPA study examining neural representations of affective meaning of social touch; likely included a healthy control group alongside ASD participants. This directly assesses social-related processing. Abstract does not state ages, but inclusion allows studies with at least one healthy group; insufficient age detail means full-text review warranted, so include for screening.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This study meets all inclusion criteria: it uses task-based fMRI during a social-related paradigm (observation of interpersonal touch), includes a healthy adult control group (21 neurotypical adults; adults in the 17–65 range implied), and reports group-level univariate whole-brain task effects for the healthy/control group (mean group effects and MNI coordinates for social vs. non-social contrasts are provided in the main/supplementary materials). Although a clinical ASD group is also included, results for the healthy group are reported separately and are generalizable to healthy adults. The paper is empirical and provides whole-brain voxelwise activation results (not limited to ROI-only or resting-state analyses). Therefore it should be included in the meta-analysis of fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

studies.title: Collective memory shapes the organization of individual memories in the medial prefrontal cortex.
studies.abstract: It has long been hypothesized that individual recollection fits collective memory. To look for a collective schema, we analysed the content of 30 years of media coverage of World War II on French national television. We recorded human brain activity using functional magnetic resonance imaging as participants recalled World War II displays at the Caen Memorial Museum following an initial tour. We focused on the medial prefrontal cortex, a key region for social cognition and memory schemas. The organization of individual memories captured using the distribution of the functional magnetic resonance imaging signal in the dorsal part of the medial prefrontal cortex was more accurately predicted by the structure of the collective schema than by various control models of contextual or semantic memory. Collective memory, which exists outside and beyond individuals, can also organize individual memories and constitutes a common mental model that connects people's memories across time and space.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI was used while participants recalled World War II displays, engaging medial prefrontal cortex and social-cognitive/collective memory processes. Study involves healthy human participants (adult sample implied) and is not a review. Age range not specified in abstract, so full-text needed to confirm eligibility.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of healthy adults (N=24, ages 22–39) investigating social-process-relevant constructs (collective memory, social knowledge, narrative comprehension, dmPFC involvement in representing collective/social schemas). The experiment used a task-evoked fMRI paradigm (recall of museum pictures cued by captions). The paper reports whole-brain analyses (surface-based searchlight, group-level TFCE permutation testing) with significant clusters for the collective-schema effect in mPFC and other regions (Extended Data Fig. 1), not limited to ROI results. All inclusion criteria are met: social-related task, healthy adult sample within 17–65, and group-level whole-brain task-evoked results. No exclusion criteria apply.

abstract_screening_results.reason: fMRI study directly investigates perception of eye gaze and face identity — social communication and perception of others — in human participants. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract does not specify participant ages or explicitly state 'healthy' but likely healthy adults; include for full-text review to confirm sample characteristics and age range.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants (self-identified White and Black) performing a social perception task (viewing in-group vs out-group faces). This addresses social-related processing (perception/understanding of others) and is not a review; abstract provides sufficient info.

fMRI study examining processing of gaze direction—a clearly social cue—reporting fusiform and connectivity effects. Appears to use healthy human participants and is not a review. Abstract does not report participant ages/health in detail, so include for full-text to confirm eligibility.

Functional MRI was conducted in healthy (normal) subjects while they passively viewed realistic movie clips depicting social interactions, a social-cognition task. This fits the review objective of social-related processing in healthy adults and is not a review or meta-analysis.

Abstract describes two fMRI experiments on understanding intentions in social interaction (theory of mind), a social-related task. The abstract does not specify participant ages or explicit healthy sample; insufficient detail to confirm ages/health, so include for full-text review to verify eligibility.

Event-related fMRI study in healthy adult participants investigating self-face recognition (Perception and Understanding of Self), a social-related process. Healthy right-handed subjects included; not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study examining impression formation (social cognition) comparing people vs objects; clearly a social-related task using functional MRI in human participants. Not a review/meta-analysis. The article is a narrative review (reviews fMRI/TMS studies) rather than a primary fMRI study reporting original data. It therefore meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

fMRI study in healthy human participants investigating self-referential processing and perspective taking (social cognition: perception/understanding of self and others). Not a review; meets task-based fMRI and population criteria based on abstract.

fMRI study with healthy (normal) adult subjects performing a social communication task (communicative speech vs description) involving social interaction and biographical familiarity; directly addresses social-related processing (Social Communication). Not a review.

fMRI study using a social interaction simulation probing friendship, empathy, and reward-related processing in 28 healthy participants (adults). Task manipulates type of relationship and emotional valence, meeting the social-related task requirement. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full review.

fMRI study of emotional facial expression processing (social communication/perception of others) in 12 healthy human participants. Meets inclusion: task is social-related and includes healthy adults. Abstract provides sufficient detail for inclusion.
Participants are children (mean age ~10.1 years), which falls outside the review’s required adult age range (17–65). Although it uses fMRI and social tasks, the age criterion is not met.

fMRI study examining observers’ neural responses to others’ social actions (perception/understanding of others). Abstract lacks explicit participant age/health details, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Study used event-related fMRI during a social task (perception of others' emotional facial expressions), involved healthy adult participants (mean age 29 ±6 within 17–65), and is not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study where participants viewed, imitated, and produced facial expressions and social hand gestures—tasks clearly involve social communication. Not a review. Abstract does not explicitly state participant ages/health, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.
Study used fMRI in macaque monkeys (non-human primates). Review requires human participants aged 17–65 performing social tasks; no human subjects are included.

fMRI study with healthy adult volunteers performing social-cognitive tasks (theory of mind: cooperation and deception). Directly examines social processing in the brain and is not a review or meta-analysis, meeting inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of neural processing of social hierarchy (a social-related task) clearly fits the review objective. The abstract does not specify participant age range or explicitly state they were healthy adults, so eligibility cannot be confirmed from the abstract alone. Include for full-text review to verify participant health status and ages (17–65).

fMRI study of self-, mother-, and abstract-other processing and a social attribution (theory-of-mind) task directly addresses social-related processing. Abstract does not specify participant ages or health status; therefore include for full-text review to confirm presence of healthy adult (17–65) sample and other eligibility details.

fMRI study involving a social interactive task (and control) in human adult participants; examines social cognition (in-group/out-group, mentalizing, affiliation-related processes). Participants appear to be healthy adults; not a review. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants examining self-recognition (face and name), which fits ‘Perception and Understanding of Self’ social-processing constructs. Not a review/meta-analysis and meets inclusion criteria based on abstract information.

fMRI study of emotion attribution (SELF/OTHER) examining empathy/social cognition in healthy male and female participants, matching the review objective of social-related fMRI in adults. Abstract does not report participant ages; include for full-text review to confirm age range and other details.

fMRI study with 18 healthy participants performing a social motor response learning task tapping inference about others’ intentions (frontal operculum/mirror system). This clearly assesses social-related processing in healthy adults; age not specified but described as healthy subjects. Include for full-text review.
Participants are children (ages 7–12); the meta-analysis requires at least one group of healthy adults aged 17–65. The abstract reports only a pediatric sample, so it does not meet the age criterion.

Event-related fMRI in healthy human subjects performing a social-communication task (gaze and pointing/following directional cues). Fits inclusion: social-related processing and healthy participants; no exclusion criteria met.

fMRI study examining neural differentiation between own vs others' body parts (self-recognition and perception of others), fitting ‘Perception and Understanding of Self’ and ‘Perception and Understanding of Others’. Uses functional MRI in human adult participants; not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study where participants judged music as human- vs computer-generated, eliciting mental state attribution (aMFC, STS, temporal poles). Task clearly probes social cognition/understanding of others; participants appear to be healthy adults and no exclusion criteria apply. Include for full-text review to extract participant ages and details.

Abstract reports an fMRI study investigating theory-of-mind/social exchange reasoning (social-related processing) and neural activations. It appears to involve human adult participants, addressing the review objective. The abstract lacks explicit participant age range/health status; include for full-text review to confirm sample comprises healthy adults (17–65) and other eligibility details.

fMRI study examining neural responses to auditory social cues (one vs two people walking), addressing social perception/understanding of others. Abstract does not report participant ages/health status; include for full-text review to confirm participants are healthy adults (17–65) and meet eligibility.

Original fMRI experiment on perception of socially relevant facial expressions/social interaction (facial mimicry) recruiting social cognition networks. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract does not state participant ages but implies healthy human subjects; include for full-text to confirm demographics and eligibility.

fMRI study where participants observed social interactions; investigates social cognition (dMPFC) and modulation by gaze. Involves human participants performing a social-related task; no indication of clinical populations. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

fMRI study where participants viewed social approach (angry vs happy faces) — a social-related task assessing perception of others. Abstract implies healthy adult participants but does not state ages/health; insufficient detail to exclude. Include for full-text review to confirm participant demographics and eligibility.

fMRI was used to measure neural responses during observation of hand and foot actions (social perception/mirror-system activity). The study examines social-cognitive processes (perception/understanding of others) in presumably healthy adult participants, meeting inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of social cognition (mPFC) where participants made social judgments about people—matches review objective. Abstract does not specify participant ages or health status, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Human fMRI study examining social processing (gaze shifts, joint attention). Abstract reports neural and behavioural responses to social vs unsocial gaze; no indication of clinical populations or that it is a review/meta-analysis. Fits inclusion criteria for fMRI social-related processing in healthy adults.

Event-related fMRI study comparing social (faces) vs non-social (shapes) stimuli during a target-detection task, directly addressing social processing. Abstract does not specify participant health status or ages, so include for full-text review to confirm presence of healthy adults.

Task involves fMRI in healthy human participants (N=14) performing a social-related task (perception of others’ pupillary responses/social salience). Not a review; meets inclusion criteria for social processing in healthy adults.

Participants are healthy children/adolescents aged 10–17; no adult (17–65) participant group is reported. Meta-analysis requires at least one group of healthy adults aged 17–65, so this study does not meet the age criterion.

fMRI study examining neural activity during general and contextual self judgments (Perception and Understanding of Self). Uses healthy adult participants across cultures and directly tests social-related processing with task-based fMRI, meeting the inclusion criteria.

Study used 3T fMRI while 21 healthy young males performed explicit emotion recognition — a social perception/understanding task. Participants are healthy adults within 17–65. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text review.
fMRI study of empathy (perception/understanding of others) involving healthy adult participants performing a social-related task; meets inclusion criteria and is not a review.

fMRI was conducted while healthy adult participants performed a social cognitive task (mental-state decoding/‘reading the mind in the eyes’), addressing perception/understanding of others. Study reports original data in healthy adult groups and is not a review.

Original fMRI study using the Trust Game to examine neural correlates of reciprocity (social cognition: perception/understanding of others, perspective-taking). Conducted in human participants (adult sample implied), not a review or meta-analysis. Fits inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

Functional MRI was used to measure neural responses to masked emotional faces (social/attachment processing) in a sample of 51 healthy adults. The task involves social-affiliative stimuli (facial emotion/attachment), and the study is empirical (not a review), meeting inclusion criteria.

fMRI study examining audiovisual integration of non-verbal vocalizations and facial movements—clearly addresses social communication/perception. Abstract reports human fMRI but does not specify participant health status or ages, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample (17–65) and other details.

Event-related fMRI study in 26 healthy adult participants examining how social context and perceived agency modulate neural responses to others' pain — a social-cognitive task (perception/understanding of others). Fits inclusion criteria (fMRI, social processing, healthy adults). Not a review/meta-analysis.

fMRI study investigating audiovisual integration of non-verbal emotional signals (social communication/perception). Appears to examine neural processing of faces/voices in humans and is not a review. Although participant ages/health are not explicitly stated in the abstract, the topic and methods strongly suggest healthy adult participants; insufficient exclusion criteria met—include for full-text confirmation of sample details.
All participants were adolescents (ages 9–17); no group of healthy adults aged 17–65 is included, so the study does not meet the age inclusion criterion for the review.

Study used fMRI during social-related tasks (direct and reflected self-appraisals — perception/understanding of self). Includes a healthy adult group (ages 23–30) within 17–65. Not a review or meta-analysis.

fMRI study investigating Theory of Mind/social cognition using a naturalistic video task (MASC) in humans; identifies neural networks for mental state reasoning. Not a review; includes healthy participants within adult age range. Fits inclusion criteria.

fMRI was conducted while participants viewed stigmatized vs. control faces — a social-cognition task (perception/understanding of others, empathy/regulation). Participants were healthy young and older adults; young adults fall within the 17–65 range. No exclusion criteria are met in the abstract.

fMRI study investigating empathy and social cognition in participants watching emotional vs. neutral social scenes. Task involves social-related processing (perception/understanding of others). Appears to involve healthy adult participants and is an original empirical study (not a review). Therefore it meets inclusion criteria.

Functional MRI was used to investigate self- and other-referential (social) processing (trait and memory judgments about self vs. friend) in healthy adult participants. No clinical sample or review; meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study using a naturalistic joint-attention paradigm to examine representation of another person’s visual content—a social cognition task (perception/understanding of others). Conducted in human participants (appears to be healthy adults); not a review. Include for full-text to confirm participant ages/details.

fMRI study of charitable donation decisions engages social cognition networks (anterior insula, posterior STC) and VMPFC value signals during a social-related task in humans. Abstract implies healthy adult participants and is not a review. Meets inclusion criteria for social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study of live face-to-face social interactions and joint attention, examining social cognition and reward-related regions. Tasks are social-related and (implicitly) conducted in healthy adult participants; fits age range and includes primary data (not a review). Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study investigating perception and production of prosody (a social-communication process) and correlations with empathy/prosodic ability. This addresses social-related processing in humans and is an original fMRI research article rather than a review. Although the abstract does not explicitly state participant ages/health, the study likely involved healthy adult participants; include for full-text confirmation if needed.

fMRI study investigating neural correlates of social expectancy violations (perception/understanding of others - warmth and competence) in human participants; not a review and appears to involve healthy adult perceivers. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in adults.

Original fMRI study investigating social-affiliative/empathetic processing (imagining loved-one vs stranger) in human participants. Task-based fMRI assessing perception/understanding of others and attachment; not a review. Participants appear to be healthy adults. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in adults.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of social preference judgments (social processing) in human participants; it meets the review objective. Participant health status and ages are not specified in the abstract, so inclusion for full-text review is needed to confirm they are healthy adults (17–65).

The article is a narrative review of PFC role in social cognition and moral judgment (Annual Review). It is not a primary fMRI study of healthy adults; exclusion criterion 'systematic reviews or meta-analyses' applies (review article).

fMRI study with healthy subjects performing familiarity judgments for personally familiar, famous, and unfamiliar faces — a social cognition task (perception/understanding of others). Not a review or meta-analysis; meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

Abstract reports fMRI activation (mPFC, posterior cingulate, temporal poles) during tasks involving mental state attribution and perception of sexualized vs. clothed targets in healthy adult participants, directly addressing social processing and meeting inclusion criteria.

Abstract describes a behavioral neuropsychological study of patients with frontal and temporo-parietal lesions (with a control group), and does not mention any fMRI scanning or functional imaging during tasks. Thus it does not meet the requirement of conducting an fMRI scan during a social-related task.

fMRI study that measured brain activity of both gesturer and guesser during charades (social communication). Investigates mirroring and mentalizing—clearly social-related processing—in what are presumably healthy adult participants. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study presenting video clips of facial-expression onsets/offsets—addresses social communication/perception of others. Uses healthy human participants (no clinical groups mentioned). Meets inclusion: functional MRI during social-related task in adults; not a review.

fMRI study (n=64) where participants judged others’ preferences — a social cognition task (perception/understanding of others). Abstract implies healthy adult participants but does not state ages/health explicitly; include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and health status.

This is a comparative/narrative review of face perception across species, not an original fMRI study in healthy adult humans performing a social-related task. No human fMRI methods or participant details are reported; thus it does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study manipulating social gaze during a task assessing social influence on action control, fitting the review objective. Abstract does not specify participant ages or explicitly state healthy adults; include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study using a social-rejection (Cyberball) task targeting social processing and reports an adult female participant group. Abstract does not specify adult ages or detailed health status; include for full-text review to confirm adults are aged 17–65 and are healthy.

Study reports fMRI experiments (n=98) in healthy adults performing social-cognitive tasks about self, friends, and others (closeness/similarity), directly addressing social-related processing. Not a review or meta-analysis and meets age/participant criteria based on abstract.

fMRI study probing empathy/sympathy (social-related processing). Sample age range 7–40 includes adults within 17–65, and no clinical populations are reported. Meets inclusion criteria for social fMRI in healthy adults; include for full-text review.

This article is a narrative review of adolescent social cognition and fMRI findings rather than an original fMRI study with primary data in healthy adult participants. It therefore meets the exclusion criterion for reviews and lacks evidence of a healthy adult (17–65) task-based fMRI group.

Functional MRI was used during a social task (Trust Game) with healthy adolescent participants, addressing social processing. Abstract does not report participant ages to confirm inclusion in the 17–65 range, so include for full-text review to verify age eligibility.

This is a resting-state fMRI functional connectivity study; no social-related task was performed during scanning. Inclusion requires fMRI during a social task in healthy adults. Not a review, but does not meet the task-based criterion.

The fMRI task is identity discrimination of faces, which falls under Perception and Understanding of Others (a social-related construct). No exclusion criteria apply. Abstract does not specify participant ages/health status, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility (healthy adults age 17–65).

Abstract describes a neuroimaging study investigating brain responses to observed social interactions (mirror and mentalizing networks), meeting the review’s focus on social processing. While the abstract does not explicitly state ‘fMRI’ or participant ages, it likely involves functional neuroimaging in healthy adults; because information is incomplete, include for full-text review to confirm methods and sample.
Participants are described as early adolescents (developmental longitudinal study); no group of healthy adults aged 17–65 is reported. Thus it does not meet the age criterion for inclusion.

3T fMRI study with 29 healthy adult participants performing a humor-processing task (social cognition/emotion). Fits inclusion criteria of social-related fMRI in healthy adults; not a review. Abstract provides sufficient info for inclusion.

Event-related fMRI study examining person perception/violations of social expectations (mentalizing). Abstract describes healthy adult participants implicitly and no clinical groups; however age range not specified. Meets social-processing fMRI criterion — include for full-text to confirm participant ages/health status.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants examining social interaction vs solitary context during learning and retrieval—task directly involves social processing (social interaction, self vs other generation). Not a review; meets inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports fMRI in normal adult volunteers viewing dynamic videos of positive/negative social encounters—clearly a social-processing task in healthy adults. Not a review/meta-analysis. Age range not explicitly stated but described as adult volunteers; therefore include for full-text screening to confirm participant ages and details.

fMRI study with 22 healthy adult male participants performing social-related tasks (judging allocentric social hierarchies and social alliances). Directly investigates perception/understanding of others; meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of prosocial behavior (mentalizing, self-control) — a social-related task. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract lacks participant age/health details, so include for full-text review to confirm participants meet 17–65 healthy criteria.

Study participants were infants (3–7 months), while the review requires healthy adult participants aged 17–65. The abstract clearly indicates no adult participant group; thus it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

fMRI study examining self-face recognition, which maps onto 'Perception and Understanding of Self' — a social-related construct. Appears to involve healthy adult participants (not reported explicitly), and is not a review. Because participant ages/clinical status are not specified in the abstract, include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI was used while healthy adult participants (n=15) viewed and rated short movie clips of social (guest-host) interactions, addressing neural correlates of social cognition. This matches the review objective and inclusion criteria; the study is not a review/meta-analysis.
Study uses fMRI of social processing but participants are adolescents (early adolescence). No participant group in the included age range (17–65) is reported, so it fails the age inclusion criterion.

fMRI study with 20 healthy adult participants performing a social-related mimicry task (eye contact, social interaction); examines neural substrates (mPFC, STS, mirror system). Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study examining social cognition (perception/understanding of others) comparing romantic partners vs roommates; involves motivated social processing. Appears to use healthy adult participants and is not a review. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in adults.

fMRI study with 20 healthy adult participants investigating cross-modal face and voice perception (social perception/communication). Meets inclusion: task is social-related processing in healthy adults; not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information for inclusion.

fMRI study where participants performed social-category (stereotype) judgments, mapping neural correlates of social cognition. Abstract describes healthy human participants (no patient groups mentioned) performing a social-related task. Age range not specified, but nothing suggests clinical samples. Abstract provides sufficient indication of relevance; include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and health.

fMRI was used while participants performed an emotional classification task (socially relevant perception/understanding of others). Study appears to involve healthy human participants and is not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study of social interaction/Theory of Mind in healthy subjects, meeting the review objective and imaging requirement. Abstract does not specify participant ages (17–65) or detailed demographics, so include for full-text review to confirm age eligibility and other details.

fMRI study using an interactive social exclusion task (ball-toss game) in human participants, examining neural responses to social relationships (same- vs opposite-gender). Appears to involve healthy adult participants and directly addresses social processing. Not a review or meta-analysis.

Study uses real-time fMRI while volunteers played the ultimatum game, a social interaction/decision-making task. It reports neural correlates of social decision behavior in human participants (not a review). Participant health appears to be healthy volunteers; fits inclusion criteria for social fMRI in adults.

fMRI study of biological motion (point-light human locomotion), which pertains to perception/understanding of others — a social-related task. Abstract does not specify participant demographics or health status; include for full-text review to confirm healthy adults (age 17–65).

Participants are male adolescents aged 11–16, not adults. The review requires at least one group of healthy participants aged 17–65. Although the study uses fMRI of social decision-making, the sample falls outside the specified adult age range.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n=22) assessing perception of affective/social touch (CT-targeted brushing). Task clearly probes social perception/cognition; meets age and sample criteria and is not a review. Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text review.

The abstract addresses neural correlates of emotional prosody comprehension, a social-communication task relevant to the review, but does not specify that fMRI was used or detail participant health/ages. Insufficient methodological/sample information to confirm inclusion criteria, so include for full-text review to verify imaging modality and healthy adult sample.

Abstract reports qualitative focus group and questionnaire data from adolescent students; no functional MRI was conducted and participants are teenagers rather than healthy adults (17–65). Does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study examining perception of in-group vs out-group actions (social perception/understanding of others), consistent with review objective. Involves human participants and task during fMRI; not a review. Abstract does not state participant ages or explicitly state health status, so include for full-text verification.

fMRI study manipulating social load during a social working memory task in healthy adults; examines social cognition-related brain activity. Not a review; meets inclusion criteria for social-processing fMRI in healthy adult participants.

Human fMRI study of empathic decision-making (choices for self vs others) targeting social-cognitive processes (empathy, other-simulation). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract does not specify participant ages or health status, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study examining social communication (communicative vs noncommunicative vocalizations) in the STS, matching the review objective. Abstract does not report participant age/health details; insufficient information to confirm inclusion criteria fully, so include for full-text review.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of social perception (affiliation vs isolation) with healthy younger and older adult participants performing a social-related task (pleasantness judgments). No review/meta-analysis and no clinical groups reported; likely includes a healthy adult group within 17–65 (younger adults). Sufficiently matches inclusion criteria for full-text review.

Primary fMRI study investigating valenced self-referential (social) processing using a self/other task in 20 healthy adult women. Fits inclusion: functional MRI during a social-related task (perception/understanding of self), healthy adult sample within target age range. Not a review.

This paper is a narrative review of adolescent social brain development rather than a primary fMRI study in healthy adult participants. It does not report an original fMRI experiment with healthy adults aged 17–65. It therefore meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

fMRI study of social evaluation/impression formation in healthy young and older adults, addressing social processing. Abstract does not specify participant ages (17–65 criterion unclear), so include for full-text review to confirm ages and eligibility.

fMRI study investigating impression updating—clearly a social perception/understanding of others task in humans. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract does not specify participant ages/health, so include for full-text to confirm participants meet 17–65 healthy adult criterion.

fMRI study in healthy participants (n=51) examining affective speech classification and theory-of-mind networks — a social-cognition task. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract indicates healthy adult sample and task directly addresses social processing, so include for full-text screening.

This article is a review of model-based fMRI approaches rather than an original fMRI study. It is a systematic review-type report discussing methods and applications, meeting the exclusion criterion for reviews/meta-analyses. The abstract does not report original human fMRI data from healthy participants performing a social task.

Primary fMRI study examining neural representations of self vs familiar/unfamiliar others (empathy/social bonding), which fits social-related processing. Abstract does not specify participant ages or health status; not obviously a review. Due to insufficient participant demographic/health detail in the abstract, include for full-text review to confirm inclusion criteria (healthy adults 17–65).

The study used fMRI while participants made decisions influenced by expert advice (a form of social influence/social cognition). It includes a healthy adult group (18+). The task addresses social-related processing (perception/understanding of others and social communication). Not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI measured brain activity while healthy adult participants watched emotional movies and rated valence/arousal, which examines perception/understanding of others and social-emotional processing. Study uses task-based functional MRI in humans and addresses social-related constructs (emotional sharing, interpersonal understanding). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI measured functional neural responses in healthy adults during a socio-affective task (witnessing others' distress) assessing compassion training; reports task-related neural activations in social-affective regions. Not a review. Meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study investigating simulation of others’ decisions—a social cognition task involving perception/understanding of others. Abstract indicates human fMRI data but does not specify participant ages or health status. Include for full-text review to confirm sample (healthy adults 17–65) and extract neural findings.

fMRI study examining social motivations (power vs affiliation) using love/power movie clips—fits social-related processing. Abstract does not specify participant ages or explicitly state health status; include for full-text review to confirm participants meet age (17–65) and healthy criteria.

Primary research fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=27) examining social intention understanding during observation of social interactions; task clearly addresses social cognition (perception/understanding of others). Not a review/meta-analysis and meets inclusion criteria. Age range not specified but sample described as participants (likely adults); sufficient evidence from abstract to include for full-text data extraction.

Functional MRI was used while 19 healthy adult participants viewed social audiovisual movie clips (social perception task). Study directly investigates social processing in healthy adults and is not a review or meta-analysis.

The fMRI tasks probe working memory and incidental episodic encoding (memory processes), not social-related processing (e.g., affiliation, social communication, self/other perception). Therefore it does not meet the review’s requirement for social-related tasks in healthy adults.

fMRI study investigating affiliative emotion (a social-related construct) in humans. Abstract implies healthy adult participants though ages not specified; meets primary inclusion criteria for social-processing fMRI. Insufficient age details—include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and health status.

fMRI was conducted while healthy adult mothers listened to their own and unfamiliar infant cries — a social/attachment-related task (Affiliation/Attachment). Participants are adults (mothers) within the eligible age range and no indication of clinical disorders; not a review. Meets inclusion criteria based on the abstract.

fMRI study of empathy and perspective-taking (self/other) in healthy human subjects performing social-related tasks (pain perception/empathy). Meets inclusion criteria for social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study includes social cognition tasks (reasoning about others’ mental states) performed by neurologically normal participants; meets inclusion of social-related fMRI in healthy adults. Not a review/meta-analysis.

fMRI study of emotional facial expressions (social communication) in humans and monkeys, and reports human neural responses—directly relevant to social processing. Abstract does not specify participant ages or explicitly state healthy adult status, so inclusion for full-text review is warranted to confirm eligibility.

Participants are adolescents (not within the required adult age range 17–65), and the fMRI task used was the Monetary Incentive Delay task (monetary reward), which is not a social-related task; maternal affiliation was measured but neural data were collected during a non-social task.

fMRI study examining neural systems for social cognition (mirror neuron and mentalizing systems) during action observation—clearly a social-related task. Abstract does not state participant ages or explicitly 'healthy adults,' so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study investigating selection between self and other visual perspectives — a social-cognitive process (perception/understanding of others). Study reports task-based fMRI in human participants (healthy adults implied), not a review or meta-analysis. Fits inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

fMRI was used to measure brain responses during action observation and execution after sensorimotor training; study investigates mirror-system responses relevant to perception/understanding of others (social processing). Participants are human adults (no clinical groups reported). Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social-related processing in healthy adults.

Combined fMRI (with eye-tracking) study directly probes social interaction vs social observation, targeting perception/understanding of others. Appears to involve healthy adult participants and is an original empirical study (not a review). Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study manipulating social versus nonsocial information in an n-back task; reports activation in social cognition and face-processing regions, so addresses social-related processing. Abstract does not specify participant ages or health status, so include for full-text review to confirm at least one healthy adult group (age 17–65).

fMRI study with healthy adult participants performing a social-related task (perception of others' pain/suffering). Results report neural responses to others’ suffering and modulation by mortality salience; not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria (social processing, healthy adults). Age not specified beyond ‘adults’ but likely within 17–65; abstract provides sufficient information for inclusion.

Abstract explicitly reports a meta-analysis component. Exclusion criteria disallow systematic reviews or meta-analyses. Although an empirical fMRI study is also reported, the presence of a meta-analysis meets the exclusion criterion.

Event-related fMRI study probing gender perception from faces (perception/understanding of others), a social processing task. Appears to involve healthy adult participants and is an original empirical study (not a review). Abstract provides sufficient evidence to include for full-text data extraction.

Event-related fMRI study in healthy adult participants performing a social task (interpersonal resource conflict and sharing); reports neural responses related to social appraisal/decision-making. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants investigating abstract vs. concrete mindsets within social cognition context. Abstract does not clearly state socially-specific tasks or stimuli, so insufficient information to rule out relevance; include for full-text review to confirm social-related processing.

fMRI study where participants made attractiveness (beauty) comparisons—this is social processing (perception/understanding of others). Human participants implied to be healthy adults; no exclusion criteria met. Thus meets inclusion for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

Study uses functional MRI during a social interaction (cyber-ball) task examining neural responses to social inclusion/exclusion and face perception; participants appear to be healthy adults and the paper addresses social processing in the brain, meeting the review’s inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports fMRI experiments in which participants performed mentalizing (social-cognitive) tasks about individuals and groups. It is empirical (not a review) and examines social processing in human participants. Although participant ages/health status are not specified in the abstract, the study should be included for full-text review to confirm inclusion criteria (healthy adults 17–65).

Empirical fMRI study using a social task (speed-dating) examining responses to romantic interest/rejection—fits social processing constructs (affiliation, perception of others). Involves healthy adult participants and is not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text extraction.

fMRI study examining communicative intentions (social communication), matching review topic. Abstract does not report participant health status or ages (17–65), so include for full-text review to confirm sample characteristics.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants (mean age 24) performing a social-related task (handholding with friend/stranger vs alone during threat). Fits inclusion criteria for social processing in healthy adults; not a review.

fMRI study examining perception and social-communicative processing of different laughter types—fits social communication/perception constructs. Abstract does not specify participant health status or ages (17–65), so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample and age range.

fMRI study of social communicative gesture observation and imitation in twenty adult participants. Directly investigates social communication/perception and reports neural activations; participants are described as healthy adults (no disorders mentioned) and age likely within 17–65. Not a review. Meets inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports altered neural activation and connectivity associated with compassion training and altruistic behavior in healthy adults, indicating neuroimaging of social-related processing. Although it does not explicitly state 'fMRI' or task details, the neural activation/connectivity findings imply functional imaging during social-emotional tasks; include for full-text review to confirm imaging modality and task specifics.

fMRI study with healthy participants (N=31) performing a social-related gambling task comparing self, friend, and antagonist, probing perception/understanding of others and reward-related social processing. Abstract does not report participant ages; include for full-text review to confirm age range falls within 17–65.

fMRI was used while participants encoded messages they later communicated — a social-communication/social-influence task involving mentalizing and reward systems. Study appears to involve healthy adult participants and is an original fMRI study (not a review). Abstract provides sufficient information to include for the review.

fMRI study in healthy participants assessing recognition of others’ action dynamics ('vitality form'), a social-perception task (perception/understanding of others). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract clearly meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study with 46 healthy volunteers performing theory-of-mind tasks about emotions, beliefs, and pain—clearly a social-related task (perception/understanding of others). Participants are human adults; not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text data extraction.

Study used functional MRI during a social-evaluation task (believed being watched by a peer), reports neural responses including MPFC engagement, and includes an adult participant group (adolescents and adults). Participants are human and presumably healthy; not a review. Thus meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social-processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study where healthy adult participants (21 males) performed a social-related task (perception/understanding of dyadic nonverbal behavior). Meets inclusion criteria and no exclusion criteria apparent from abstract.

fMRI study with healthy participants performing an impression-formation task (social perception/understanding of others). Reports neural (dorsomedial PFC) activity during a social task. Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of social perception (biological motion) in humans; includes adult participants and reports adult results (healthy adults implied). Task assesses social perception, fitting the review objective. Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text data extraction.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants using social-related tasks (eye-gaze detection, self-propelling motion, and implicit mental inference). Fits inclusion criteria (social processing, healthy adults 17–65). Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text data extraction.

fMRI was used during a social task (third-party punishment, attribution of others’ intentions), and participants are described as lay people (presumably healthy adults). Age range not specified in abstract; insufficient to confirm ages, so include for full-text review.

fMRI study assessing socio-cognitive processing (viewing social driving videos) comparing groups of drivers; involves healthy adult participants and directly examines social cognition. Not a review. Abstract meets inclusion criteria.

Abstract is described as a review and lacks participant, task, and sample health/age details. It mentions human fMRI findings but does not provide enough information to confirm primary fMRI data in healthy adults. Insufficient information to determine eligibility, so include for full-text review.

fMRI study using face stimuli (social perception) with a continuous sample from childhood through adulthood; adult participants are included (adulthood) and task probes social-related face processing. No exclusion criteria met. Full text may be checked to confirm exact adult age range (17–65).

fMRI was used while participants evaluated personal attributes (a social-cognitive task: perception/understanding of self/others). No indication of clinical populations; likely healthy adults. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in adults. Age range not specified, so moderate-high confidence (0.90) to include for full-text review.

Non-human animal study: fMRI and behavioral framework discussed for songbirds, not human participants. Does not involve healthy adult humans (age 17–65) performing a social-related task; therefore it does not meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract/title indicates brain responses during evaluation of face approachability (a social task). However the abstract does not explicitly state use of fMRI or participant ages/health. Insufficient information to confirm imaging modality and sample details, so include for full-text review to verify fMRI and healthy adult sample.

Study reports functional MRI experiments in healthy adult participants using a social/empathy task (visuo-tactile paradigm assessing emotional egocentricity bias) and identifies task-related activations. It is an original empirical fMRI study of social cognition, not a review, meeting inclusion criteria.

Event-related fMRI paradigm directly examines processing of social vs nonsocial gestures (social cognition). Abstract does not state participant health status or ages; likely healthy adults but insufficient detail. Include for full-text review to confirm participants meet healthy adult (17–65) criterion.

fMRI study with human participants performing collaborative vs. competitive tasks (social contexts). Investigates social motivation and social-cognition brain regions (TPJ, reward circuits). Meets inclusion criteria (social-related task, healthy adults likely; not a review).

Abstract reports an fMRI study where participants received tactile stimulation and judged ambiguous social interactions (social perception/understanding). Neural activations (somatosensory cortices, amygdala, hippocampus, prefrontal cortex) are reported. Participants appear to be healthy adults. No exclusion criteria met.

Abstract reports functional MRI (fMRI) responses to guilt in healthy individuals performing a task probing moral sentiments (social processing). Although the primary analysis focused on structural VBM, fMRI data related to social/moral emotions are explicitly described, meeting inclusion criteria.

Study used simultaneous fMRI during live verbal interaction (social communication) in healthy adult participants (11 pairs of female friends). Directly assesses social-related processing with functional imaging and is not a review, meeting inclusion criteria.

fMRI study with 44 healthy participants performing explicit social trait judgments (trustworthiness, attractiveness) using voice stimuli, directly addressing social processing in healthy adults. No exclusion criteria met. Include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and additional details.

fMRI study presenting video clips assessing empathy and social communication; participants performed a social-related task. Reports BOLD responses and connectivity in modality-related regions; not a review. Participants appear to be healthy adults. Fits inclusion criteria for social-processing fMRI in healthy adults.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of social-cognitive processes (empathy, Theory of Mind, self–other differentiation) in human participants, matching the review objective. The abstract does not specify participant ages or explicitly state health status; therefore inclusion for full-text review is warranted to confirm that at least one group are healthy adults (17–65).

Abstract reports event-related fMRI during one-shot, anonymous prisoner's dilemma—a social cognition task (cooperation/understanding others) with neural activations in mPFC, TPJ, precuneus. It is an original fMRI study (not a review). Participant health status and ages are not specified in the abstract; likely healthy adults but need full text to confirm demographics. Include for full-text review to verify sample meets age/health criteria.

Abstract reports the author’s fMRI studies examining social emotions (guilt, embarrassment, pride, envy) in humans and discusses social neuroscience and decision-making, indicating relevant fMRI social-task data. It does not specify participant health status or ages, nor methodological details. Not clearly a systematic review/meta-analysis. Insufficient information to confirm healthy adult sample and task specifics, so include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

This study used rhesus monkeys (non-human primates) with single-unit recordings and fMRI-defined patches, not fMRI in human participants performing social-related tasks. It does not involve healthy adult humans (age 17–65) or a human social-processing task, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study comparing neural responses to familiar vs. unfamiliar faces (social perception/understanding of others). Includes an age-matched control group of healthy adults. Although centered on a patient with Capgras, the presence of healthy participants and a social-related task meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study using the ultimatum game examining social decision-making networks, which matches the review objective (social processing). Abstract does not specify participant ages or whether a healthy adult group (17–65) was included. Insufficient information to confirm age criteria—include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

fMRI study reporting brain activity during live social exchanges (reciprocal imitation), addressing social cognition (Mirror and Mentalizing systems). Appears to involve human participants performing a social-related task; not a review. No indication of clinical populations; meets inclusion criteria for healthy adult fMRI social processing studies.

fMRI study in healthy adults examining brain responses to interpersonal manual touch (holding, smoothing, poking). Interpersonal touch is a social stimulus relevant to social interaction/affiliation, meeting the review’s inclusion criteria. Not a review/meta-analysis.

Abstract reports examination of neural substrates of social cognition and face processing in healthy young adults, matching the review topic and population. However, it does not specify that an fMRI task was used or provide task details; include for full-text review to confirm imaging modality and task.

Human fMRI study investigating social distance (photographs of participants' friends vs acquaintances) alongside spatial/temporal distance. Involves social-related processing (social familiarity/affiliation) in likely healthy adult participants. Not a review article. Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text data extraction.

Abstract reports task-based functional MRI during a social closeness task (photos of friends vs unknown people), clearly addressing social processing in human participants. Participant health and exact ages aren’t specified in the abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm adult (17–65) healthy sample.

fMRI study examining social-related processes (direct and reflected self- and other-evaluations). Includes a healthy young adult group aged 22–31 (within 17–65). Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info to meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of social influence (bystander effect) while participants witnessed an emergency—this is a social-related task probing perception/understanding of others and action preparation. It describes human participants scanned with fMRI. The abstract does not specify participant ages/health explicitly, so include for full-text review to confirm they are healthy adults (17–65).
Participants are non-human (dogs). Meta-analysis requires fMRI studies of healthy human adults (age 17–65); this study does not meet participant criteria.

fMRI study of social cognitive processing (attribution to self/other/situation) in a typical (healthy) adult sample. Task assesses social perception/understanding of others/self. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text data extraction.

The study reports an fMRI experiment where participants attributed states of awareness to a cartoon face (social attribution/perception of others). Participants appear to be healthy adults and this is primary research (not a review). Thus it meets the fMRI social-processing inclusion criteria.

fMRI study examining neural correlates of social exclusion (Cyberball) and responses (punishment/forgiveness) during a social decision task (modified Dictator Game). Involves human participants and social cognitive processes; not a review. Abstract sufficiently indicates relevance to social-related processing in healthy adults; include for full-text extraction.

fMRI study investigating anticipatory sensorimotor processes during active interpersonal touch versus inanimate touch — a social-related task involving perception/understanding of others. Appears to involve human participants and is an original fMRI study (not a review). The abstract does not specify participant ages, so full text should be checked, but inclusion is warranted for full-text review.

fMRI study examining self- and other-referential recollection (social cognition: perception/understanding of self and others). Not a review. Abstract does not report participant ages/health explicitly, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Abstract reports an fMRI experiment in healthy adult participants assessing self-referential processing during intergroup competition (a social cognitive task) and links neural responses to willingness to harm competitors. This clearly meets the review’s inclusion criteria (fMRI, social-related processing, healthy participants). Not a review or meta-analysis.

fMRI study in healthy human participants (n=25) measuring responses to faces; facial color processing relates to social communication/perception of others, fitting the review’s social-related processing objective. Abstract lacks explicit ages but otherwise meets inclusion.

Abstract reports fMRI data collected in Berlin during a face-to-face social feedback task where healthy German and Chinese adult participants updated self- and other-trait ratings. This directly addresses social processing (self/other understanding) in healthy adults and is not a review. Meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study investigating social influence/emotion alignment during a social interaction task; reports neural activity in healthy participants. Meets inclusion (social-related task, fMRI, human participants). No exclusion criteria met. Age not specified in abstract, so full text should be checked, but abstract provides sufficient basis to include for full-text review.

fMRI study with a non-clinical sample of 20 young adult male participants performing empathy-related social-interaction tasks (viewing first-person social scenarios). Targets social perception/understanding in healthy adults (age within 17–65) and is not a review.

fMRI study examining perception/understanding of others’ social interactions (third-person perspective), meeting the social-related task criterion. Abstract does not specify participant ages or explicitly state healthy sample; insufficient to exclude. Include for full-text review to confirm participant details and eligibility.

3T fMRI study where participants (presumably healthy adults) performed a social-related task (imagining triadic interactions). Reports neural activity in mentalizing and mirror systems. Not a review/meta-analysis and fits inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study using an ultimatum game probing fairness (social decision-making/perception of others), meeting the social-task requirement. Abstract does not specify participant ages or health status, so inclusion cannot be confirmed solely from abstract; include for full-text review to verify healthy adult sample (17–65).

Study used fMRI during a social interaction task (Taylor Aggression Paradigm) presenting angry/neutral facial expressions and examined neural responses in healthy participants. Fits review objective (social processing in healthy adults). Age range not specified in abstract; include for full-text to confirm ages and other details.

fMRI was conducted while healthy adult participants (N=16) performed a social interaction task (matching-pennies) involving human and non-human agents. The study examines perception and understanding of others (social cognition), matching the review objective. Not a review or meta-analysis.

Primary data fMRI study of impression formation (social evaluation of others) in humans. Task is social-cognitive (person evaluation), uses functional MRI, and implies healthy adult participants. Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI was used while participants performed an implicit false-belief (theory-of-mind) social task, directly addressing social processing. Abstract does not specify participant ages or explicitly state healthy adults, so inclusion for full-text review is warranted to confirm eligibility.

Abstract reports a task-based neuroimaging study of interpersonal synchrony and social affiliation in human participants (n=100). The study examines social-cognitive processes and reports brain-area involvement, consistent with functional neuroimaging during a social task in healthy adults. Although the abstract does not explicitly state “fMRI” or participant ages, it clearly addresses social processing and warrants full-text review to confirm imaging modality and age range.

fMRI study with 20 healthy adult male volunteers viewing campaign videos designed to elicit empathy—a social cognitive process (understanding others). Meets inclusion: task-based fMRI, social-related processing, healthy participants (adults). Not a review/meta-analysis.

fMRI study in humans examining cross-modal recognition of others (voice-face identity), which is social perception of others. Uses healthy human participants (adults implied). Meets criteria of social-related task and fMRI; no exclusion criteria met.

Resting-state (task-free) fMRI study focusing on ATL connectivity with the language network; no social-related task was performed. Although ATL is linked to social cognition in general, the abstract reports no social processing task, so it does not meet the task-based inclusion criterion.

fMRI study in humans examining neural responses to biological (social) vs scrambled motion, addressing perception/decoding of social signals (Perception and Understanding of Others). Appears to involve healthy adult participants and meets the review’s inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

fMRI was used while healthy adult participants (N=50, young adults within 17–65) performed a social-related task (labeling brief emotional facial expressions — perception/understanding of others). Study is empirical neuroimaging, not a review, meeting inclusion criteria.
Participants were non-human (domestic dogs) undergoing fMRI; the review requires human participants age 17–65. Therefore the study does not meet the population inclusion criterion.

Empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants examining social-affiliative processing (social sharing of emotions) during task performance; functional MRI was used and the sample comprises healthy friends. Not a review. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in adults.

fMRI study where participants processed social communication (text messages believed to be from a friend vs. a computer). Involves healthy adult participants (no clinical groups reported) and examines social-related processing (social communication, mental state processing). Not a review; meets inclusion criteria.

Original fMRI study using model-driven fMRI during a public good (social decision-making) task examining neural correlates of social tie formation and prosocial behavior in human participants. Meets inclusion: task is social-related, functional MRI used, healthy adult participants implied. Not a review/meta-analysis.

Abstract describes a social communication task with cerebral activity measured in healthy communicators but does not specify fMRI. Insufficient imaging-modality detail; include for full-text review to confirm fMRI and eligibility.

Abstract describes hyperscanning methods and a review/discussion of EEG, fMRI, fNIRS techniques rather than reporting an original fMRI experiment with healthy adults performing a social task. No participants, task, or fMRI results are reported; thus it does not meet inclusion criteria.
Animal (mouse) resting-state fMRI study; no human participants or task-based social processing. Does not meet inclusion criteria of fMRI in healthy adult humans performing social-related tasks.

fMRI study investigating neural correlates of initiating/responding to joint attention—a social communication task—in human participants. Abstract indicates experimental fMRI in an interactive social paradigm but does not specify participant ages/health; include for full-text review to confirm sample characteristics and eligibility.

Abstract reports fMRI during a dyadic social task (eye contact) and identifies neural networks for reciprocal social interaction, aligning with the review objective. However, participant health status and age range (17–65) are not specified in the abstract, so full-text review is needed to confirm sample eligibility.

fMRI study with 37 healthy adult participants performing a social-communication task (evaluating feeling of being addressed). Examines neural processing of social cues (gesture and body orientation). Not a review or meta-analysis, meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study measuring neural responses while participants performed a social perception task (judging congruent vs. incongruent person dyads). Participants are healthy adults; study is empirical (not a review). Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

fMRI study examining perception/understanding of others’ emotions in dynamic crowds (social perception task). Abstract does not specify participant ages or health status, so inclusion cannot be confirmed from abstract alone. Per guideline, include for full-text review to verify healthy adult (17–65) sample and other details.

fMRI study where participants made strategic decisions to lie or tell the truth in a game-theoretic social interaction, probing social cognition (deception, understanding others). Involves healthy adult participants (typical sample) and is not a review; meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

Participants are adolescents (ages 12–15), but the meta-analysis requires healthy adults aged 17–65. Although it uses fMRI and a social task, the sample falls outside the eligible age range, so exclude.

Study uses resting-state fMRI in children aged 3–5 and investigates developmental DMN connectivity; does not involve a social-related task nor include healthy adult participants (17–65). Does not meet inclusion criteria.
Participants are older adults (mean age 79), outside the review’s required age range (17–65). No group of healthy participants within 17–65 is reported, so the study does not meet inclusion criteria.

Original fMRI study with 18 adult participants performing a social-cognitive task (predicting others’ behavior; theory-of-mind and deontic inference). Involves social processing and healthy adult sample; not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports original dfMRI experimental results on reciprocal eye-contact (a social interaction) and analyses of BOLD responses; not a review. Participant characteristics (health status, age range) are not specified in the abstract, so full-text is needed to confirm inclusion criteria (healthy adults 17–65). Include for full-text review.

This is a theoretical/narrative paper discussing explanations for mirror-touch synesthesia; the abstract does not report conducting an fMRI study or list participants. It reviews fMRI evidence but is not an original fMRI experiment with healthy adult participants, so it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

Original fMRI study investigating attributional processes about others (social cognition) in humans. Uses functional MRI during a social-related task (attributing beliefs/motives) and reports findings in healthy adult participants. Not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social processing.

fMRI study investigating social-affective modulation of mimicry (affiliation, social perception) using facial stimuli—clearly a social-related task. Abstract does not specify participant ages or health status; therefore include for full-text review to confirm participants are healthy adults within 17–65.

Task-based fMRI study in young, healthy adults examining social reward processing (social vs monetary) using an incentive delay task. Fits review focus on social-related processing in healthy adults and is not a review or meta-analysis.

Human fMRI study examining social working memory and perspective-taking neural correlates; addresses social processing in healthy adults. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract clearly reports task-based fMRI of social cognitive processes, so meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study investigating gaze following and social attention (perception/understanding of others) in human participants. Appears to use healthy adult participants and meets inclusion criteria; not a review or meta-analysis.

Empirical fMRI study of social perception/cognition in human participants (STS responses to social and linguistic stimuli). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract does not specify participant ages, but it implies healthy adult participants; insufficient age detail warrants full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study where participants judged actions at different levels of abstraction, engaging mental-state reasoning and action-representation networks—fits social cognitive processing. Not a review. Abstract implies healthy adult participants; age not specified, but per instructions inclusion is appropriate for full-text review if uncertain.

fMRI study using gender identification of angry and happy faces (social-emotional processing) with N=30 participants. Abstract does not explicitly state participants’ health status or ages, so full text needed to confirm they are healthy adults (17–65). No exclusion criteria met.

Study reports fMRI in 164 healthy adult subjects performing an interactive social/mentalizing task (Prisoner’s Dilemma) assessing attachment-related social processing. Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants performing an imitation task related to social behavior (imitation underpinning language and social interaction). Directly examines social-related processing (urge to imitate and associated neural correlates). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text review.

fMRI task involved social-related processing (responses to parents; mentalizing/social cognition). Sample are healthy adolescents with mean age 17 (within the 17–65 inclusion range). Not a review. Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text review.

Participants are infants (4–7 months), not healthy adults aged 17–65; no adult participant group is reported. Although it investigates social-related voice processing, it does not meet the inclusion criterion of at least one healthy adult group.

Abstract reports a functional neuroimaging (fMRI) study in which participants viewed social scenes (a social cognition/mentalizing task) and linked dmPFC responses to daily social behavior; sample appears to be healthy adults. This matches inclusion criteria for fMRI of social-related processing in healthy adults. No exclusion criteria met.

fMRI study directly investigates social-reputation processing (a social-related task) in male and female participants, matching the review objective. Abstract does not specify participant ages or explicit health status; insufficient demographic detail to confirm inclusion criteria, so include for full-text review to verify age and health.

EmpaToM is an fMRI study manipulating empathy and Theory of Mind—social cognitive processes (Perception/Understanding of Others). Large samples (N=90, N=178) indicate healthy adult participants; not a review. Satisfies inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study where healthy adult participants performed a gaze-following task probing social attention/perception of others, directly addressing social-related processing. No exclusion criteria met. Abstract does not state participant ages explicitly, so include for full-text review to confirm demographics and methodology.

The abstract addresses Theory of Mind (a social cognitive process) relevant to the review objective but does not specify whether an fMRI was conducted or report participant demographics/health status. Insufficient methodological detail in the abstract — include for full-text review to determine fMRI use and sample of healthy adults.

Abstract reports fMRI of negative emotion processing and sex differences in fronto-limbic connectivity in (presumably) healthy adults, but does not specify whether the task involved social-related stimuli or processes. Insufficient information to determine eligibility for a social-processing meta-analysis — include for full-text review.

fMRI was used while participants performed an empathy-for-pain task involving ingroup/outgroup (social processing: perception/understanding of others). Sample: 30 healthy adult participants. Not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of social perception (observers viewing violent social interactions; attention to aggressor vs victim) fits social-related processing. Abstract describes task and neural outcomes but does not explicitly state participant health status or ages; insufficient detail to confirm inclusion criteria, so include for full-text review.
