Functional MRI was used while participants read passages varying in social content; the study examines social cognition/theory of mind and links dmPFC activity to social cognitive performance. Participants appear to be healthy adults. This fits the fMRI social-processing inclusion criteria and is not a review.

Study uses resting-state fMRI in macaque monkeys (non-human) and does not involve human participants performing a social-related task. Inclusion requires task-based fMRI in healthy adults (age 17–65).

Abstract reports an fMRI experiment examining self-referential and social stimulus processing in humans, matching the review objective. However, it does not state participant health status or ages (17–65). Include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample and eligibility.

fMRI study using the Cyberball social exclusion task (a social-related paradigm) in human participants; reports neural activity linked to social processing (emotion regulation) and behavioral measures (romantic relationship satisfaction). No indication this is a review or that participants are outside healthy adult range. Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text data extraction.

fMRI study examining disgust perception in racial prejudice during a passive face-viewing task—clearly social perception/understanding of others. Abstract implies healthy participants and does not mention clinical groups. Age range not specified, so full text should be checked, but abstract meets primary inclusion criteria; include for full-text review.

fMRI study investigating social cognition (agency and communion) using a valence classification task with reported neural activations; not a review. Abstract implies human participants performing a social-related task but does not specify ages/health. Include for full-text review to confirm participant age range and health status.

The abstract explicitly states the paper is a review of studies (not an original fMRI experiment). It focuses on development in children and ASD and does not report fMRI data collected in healthy adults (17–65). Thus it meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

fMRI study investigating social communication (understanding speech acts: Requests vs Naming) in human participants. Abstract implies healthy adult participants but does not report ages; content clearly matches review objective. Include for full-text review to confirm sample age range and health status.

Original fMRI hyperscanning study of mutual gaze and joint attention (social processing) in human participant pairs. It reports task-based fMRI neural synchronization related to shared attention; not a review. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

This fMRI study directly investigates social vs. nonsocial gesture processing and neural correlates, matching the review objective. The abstract does not explicitly state participant health status or exact ages, so inclusion requires full-text confirmation of a healthy adult sample (17–65). Include for full-text review to verify sample characteristics and eligibility.

fMRI study examining explicit control of interpersonal trust/distrust (social attitude processing) in a sample of healthy participants (n=60). The task is social-related (perception/attitudes toward others) and the study is primary research (not a review). Age range not stated in abstract, but inclusion criteria allow healthy adult groups; include for full-text review to confirm ages.

Empirical fMRI study in healthy adult social networks; participants viewed faces of others (social cognition task). Whole-brain fMRI collected during social-related processing (popularity, social valuation, mentalizing). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study with 26 healthy adult participants performing an empathy-evoking social cognition task (film clips with contextual cues and music). Investigates empathic concern and neural connectivity during social processing. Meets inclusion criteria (functional MRI during social-related task in healthy adults) and is not a review.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants investigating social-interactive processing (mentalizing) during speech perception. Tasks directly probe social cognition/perception of others; matches inclusion criteria and no exclusion criteria met from abstract.

fMRI study employing MVPA during social cognition (‘thinking about others’ mental states’), directly addressing social processing. Abstract does not specify participant ages or clinical status; because inclusion requires at least one healthy adult group and this is unclear from the abstract, include for full-text review to confirm demographics and eligibility.

fMRI study with healthy participants (N=26) performing a social task (learning about others' generosity). Directly addresses social processing in healthy adults and is an original empirical study, not a review. Age range not specified in abstract, but participant group appears to be healthy adults; include for full-text review to confirm ages and details.

The abstract describes an original fMRI study using dyadic (live eye contact) social interaction—clearly a social-related task probing empathy/default-mode networks. Participant health/ages are not specified in the abstract, so inclusion requires full-text review to confirm at least one healthy adult (17–65) group.

Study uses fMRI with the right pSTS as a social-communication-related target and reports simultaneous rt-fMRI/EEG during a neurofeedback paradigm, which aligns with the review objective. Abstract lacks details on participant health status, ages, and specific task, so inclusion for full-text review is warranted to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study examining guilt-related social cognition (affective and social cognition regions) during imagined and recollected guilt tasks—clearly a social-related task. Abstract lacks explicit participant age/health details; no exclusion criteria met. Include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample and extract relevant contrasts.
Non-human subjects: study used three macaque monkeys. Meta-analysis requires fMRI studies with healthy human adults (ages 17–65). Therefore it does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n=21) performing affective theory-of-mind judgments—a social-cognitive task (perception/understanding of others). Not a review/meta-analysis and meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

fMRI study with 20 healthy adult participants receiving empathic vs. unempathic social responses after negative feedback—addresses social cognition/empathy (Perception and Understanding of Others). Fits inclusion criteria (task-based fMRI, healthy adults). Not a review/meta-analysis.

Human fMRI block-design study examining neural responses to perception of facial expressions (social communication / perception of others) in face-selective regions. This meets the review objective of fMRI studies of social processing in likely healthy adult participants; not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text data extraction.
The study used fMRI for social joint-attention but participants were children and adolescents; no healthy adult group in the 17–65 range is reported, so it fails the age inclusion criterion.

fMRI study with 37 healthy adult participants performing a social-evaluative task (watching approving/disapproving social videos). Task assesses social perception/understanding; fits review objective of social-related fMRI in healthy adults. Not a review/meta-analysis.

The study used fMRI during a trustworthiness-rating task probing social cognition (perception/understanding of others). Though participant ages/health not explicitly stated in the abstract, it appears to involve healthy adult participants; no exclusion criteria (e.g., review article) apply. Include for full-text review to confirm participant demographics and ages.

fMRI experiment examining person perception and mentalising (social cognition) in human participants; fits social-related task criteria. Not a review. Abstract indicates direct neuroimaging of forming representations of others, meeting inclusion. Participant health/age not specified but typical fMRI study likely healthy adults; include for full-text review.
The study used domestic dogs as participants (non-human), whereas the review requires fMRI studies in human adults (age 17–65). Therefore it does not meet the participant inclusion criteria.

This is an essay/review advocating cross-species social neuroscience, not an original fMRI study. The abstract reports no human participants or fMRI data and fits the exclusion of reviews/meta-analyses.

fMRI study examining theory-of-mind/social processing across social and non-social contexts. Abstract reports neural responses during mental state reasoning and does not indicate a review or clinical-only sample. Participant age/health not specified—include for full-text confirmation.

Functional MRI conducted while healthy adult participants (N=23) performed a visually-based social judgment task (evaluating social dominance in faces), which directly assesses social cognitive processing. The sample consists of healthy adults and the study is empirical (not a review). Fits inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing.

fMRI study manipulating attention to social meaning vs physical properties of artifacts, reporting activations in social cognition regions (mPFC, TPJ, precuneus, insula). Appears to involve healthy adult participants; meets review objective of social-related processing in fMRI. No exclusion criteria met. Include for full-text review to confirm participant ages/health if needed.

fMRI study of social interaction (virtual ball-toss) in a sample of 38 healthy adult participants examining social reward processing and neural activation. Meets inclusion: task is social-related and uses fMRI in healthy adults (no disorders reported).

Task-state fMRI examining episodic memory retrieval emphasizing self-referential processing (a social-cognitive construct). The study includes control (healthy) participants but ages are not reported and sample focuses on aging/aMCI, so unclear if healthy group is within 17–65. Abstract lacks sufficient info — include for full-text review.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants performing socially-induced cognitive emotion regulation (social cognition/attachment). Task involves a psychotherapist’s social regulation of emotion, addressing affiliation/attachment and social cognition. Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient detail to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of social interaction/retaliation (provocation paradigm) in healthy adult volunteers; examines social-emotional processing (anger/retaliation) relevant to perception/understanding of others. Not a review. Participant group comprises healthy adults (males), fitting age criterion assumption.

Abstract reports neural correlates of mentalizing (a social-cognition construct) and likely neuroimaging, but does not explicitly state an fMRI task was used or provide participant age/health details. Insufficient information to confirm inclusion—include for full-text review.

Abstract describes an fMRI study probing social cognition (empathy, perspective taking, attentional reorienting) using charitable giving and EmpaToM tasks. It clearly fits the review objective of social-related processing in humans. The abstract does not explicitly state participant ages/health status, so full-text review is needed to confirm inclusion criteria (healthy adults 17–65). Given clear use of fMRI and social tasks, include for full-text screening.

Abstract reports resting and unspecified task fMRI but does not indicate social-related tasks. Inclusion requires a social task; abstract lacks this detail, so eligibility cannot be determined from abstract alone. Include for full-text review to confirm whether tasks involved social processing.

Task-based fMRI study assessing empathy and mentalizing in a large sample of healthy adults (N=178). Reports neural analyses (dynamic causal modeling) during social-emotional tasks. Participants are healthy and within the eligible age range; not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria.

Participants were preadolescents (age 11) rather than adults; the meta-analysis requires healthy participants aged 17–65. Although it is an fMRI social-processing task, the sample age falls outside the inclusion criteria.

fMRI study investigating theory-of-mind/social cognition during cooperative vs competitive interactions with human partners; clearly a social-related task in healthy adults (typical adult sample in NeuroImage paper). Not a review. Meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI was used while participants performed a social cognition task (inferring others’ emotions), directly addressing perception/understanding of others. Abstract does not specify participant ages or explicit health status; insufficient to confirm exclusion. Include for full-text review to verify healthy adult sample (age 17–65) and other details.

Abstract does not report an fMRI study or social-processing task in healthy adults. It examines gene–environment interactions and response inhibition in adolescents (likely including clinical ADHD context), so it does not meet the review’s fMRI/social processing in healthy adult criteria.
Participants are healthy children (mean age 10.2 years). Meta-analysis requires healthy adult participants aged 17–65; thus the study population does not meet the age inclusion criterion.

fMRI study examining neural mechanisms of impression updating/perception of others (social cognition) in human participants; not a review/meta-analysis. Likely uses healthy adult participants and meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI studies.

fMRI study investigating Theory of Mind (social processing) in 19 healthy human participants. Task manipulates mental state inference and contextual adjustments (clearly social cognition). Although exact ages not reported in abstract, participants are described as healthy adults; study fits inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

Participants were adolescents (minors). The study sample is described as adolescents with no indication of participants aged 17–65; therefore it does not meet the review’s adult age inclusion criterion.

fMRI study using a social task (Ultimatum Game) assessing cooperative decision-making and neural correlates; appears to be an empirical study with intervention groups. Abstract does not explicitly state participant health status or ages, so include for full-text review to confirm participants are healthy adults (17–65).
Participants are children in middle childhood (roughly ages 7–13), not within the review's required adult age range (17–65). Although it uses fMRI and a social task, the age criterion is not met.

fMRI study in human subjects includes a theory-of-mind (social attribution) task probing social cognition; participants appear to be healthy adults and no exclusion criteria are met. Age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text verification.

fMRI study using a modified Cyberball task combining social exclusion and performance evaluation, directly investigates social processing and neural correlates. Not a review. Abstract does not report participant ages or clinical status, but likely healthy adults; include for full-text to confirm sample characteristics.

The abstract describes a narrative/review discussion of ecstatic epilepsy and related phenomena using various imaging methods (fMRI, PET, SPECT) and case studies. It does not report an original fMRI experiment in healthy adults performing a social-related task, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study with 34 participants investigating neural responses to social interactions during naturalistic movie viewing. Targets social cognition/perception of others (DMPFC), includes healthy participants. Abstract lacks explicit participant ages; include for full-text review to confirm ages (17–65) and health status.

fMRI study of social processing: participants watched actors in angry vs. joyful social situations (perception/understanding of others). Twenty healthy adult participants underwent task-based fMRI. Not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study explicitly investigates self-reference versus reference to others—a social cognition task—meeting the review objective. The abstract does not specify participant health status or ages; inclusion is uncertain from abstract alone, so include for full-text review to confirm presence of healthy adults (17–65).

fMRI experiments were conducted with healthy adult participants performing social tasks (Prisoner’s Dilemma, Ultimatum Game), directly assessing social-related processing. Sample sizes and task details are provided and this is an original empirical study (not a review). Meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study with healthy participants examining attachment-related social cognition (mentalizing) vs control scenes; matches review objective. Age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm participants are adults (17–65).

Abstract reports fMRI findings (perigenual ACC and dorsomedial frontal area 9) during social interactions (cooperation/competition and self-other processing) in human participants. Participant health status and ages are not specified in the abstract; therefore include for full-text review to confirm presence of healthy adults aged 17–65.

fMRI study of social cooperation (one-shot prisoner's dilemma) in healthy adult participants; examines neural responses to mutual cooperation (ventral striatum, OFC). Not a review. Meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study in healthy adults (N=38) performing mental state judgments (social cognition/mentalizing) using naturalistic social interaction stimuli. Directly addresses perception/understanding of others during fMRI, meets inclusion criteria and is not a review.

Abstract describes a narrative review of adolescent neurobiology, not an original fMRI study. It is a review article (meets exclusion criterion: systematic review/meta-analysis) and focuses on adolescents rather than healthy adults. No primary fMRI methods or eligible adult participants reported.

Abstract reports task-based fMRI of reappraisal of angry faces (socially relevant perception/understanding of others) and functional connectivity related to regulation success, matching the review objective. The abstract does not explicitly state participant health status or ages; therefore include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample (17–65). Not a review or meta-analysis.
The fMRI study was conducted in dogs (canine subjects), not human participants. The review requires human healthy adults (age 17–65); therefore the study does not meet the population criterion.

Original fMRI study examining prosocial learning and empathy (social cognition) where participants performed tasks benefiting self vs others. Meets review objective of social-related processing with neuroimaging. Abstract implies human participants in fMRI and is not a review/meta-analysis. Although participant ages/health not explicitly stated, inclusion should proceed to full-text to confirm sample meets 17–65 healthy adult criterion.

Human fMRI study examining mentalizing, empathy, and prosocial behavior (social cognition). Tasks directly assess perception/understanding of others and prosocial responses. No indication participants were clinical; fits healthy adult fMRI inclusion. No exclusion criteria met.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants (25 females) performing a social-cognitive task about kin and friends; addresses social processing constructs (perception/understanding of others, affiliation). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient detail to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study using a face emotional processing paradigm addresses social perception/understanding of others. Abstract does not specify participant health status or ages; insufficient information to confirm inclusion criteria, so include for full-text review.

fMRI study examining social competition (a social-related process) with neural measures (mPFC, precuneus/PCC). No exclusion criteria met. Abstract lacks explicit participant age/health details, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample and age range.

Abstract reports neuroimaging of neural responses to social language and re-transmission—relevant to social processing. However, it does not explicitly state that functional MRI was used nor provide participant age/health details. Insufficient detail to confirm fMRI or sample; include for full-text review.

This article is an explicit review (‘In this review’) of neuroimaging studies, not an original fMRI study reporting task-based data from healthy adult participants. It meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses and provides no primary fMRI results for inclusion.

Abstract describes face recognition and neural correlates related to oxytocin receptor variation but does not specify that fMRI was used during a social task. Insufficient information to determine whether study meets fMRI-in-social-task criterion; include for full-text review to confirm imaging modality, task, and participant health/age.

fMRI study of social processing (emotion recognition and eye-gaze integration) in healthy adults; includes a younger healthy group aged 17–27 meeting the 17–65 age criterion. Not a review/meta-analysis.

fMRI study examining neural responses to empathy for pain (a social-related task) and prosocial behavior in human participants. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract does not indicate exclusions (likely healthy sample); include for full-text review to confirm participant ages/health status.

fMRI study with healthy human participants performing social-cognitive tasks (passive observation and explicit emotion judgments of faces), directly addressing perception/understanding of others. Not a review/meta-analysis. Age range not specified in abstract, so full-text should confirm demographics, but abstract provides sufficient basis to include for full-text review.

The study used EEG (mu rhythm) with source localisation, not functional MRI. The review seeks fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults; modality mismatch excludes this study despite involving social emotion classification.

fMRI study of 40 healthy volunteers performing a social-related task (viewing masked and unmasked facial emotions, including affiliation-relevant emotions). Participants are healthy adults; the task targets social perception/understanding of others. Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient detail to meet inclusion criteria.

This study is a coordinate-based meta-analysis (activation likelihood estimation; 30 articles). The exclusion criteria explicitly remove systematic reviews or meta-analyses. Although it addresses fMRI social processing in healthy adults, it meets the exclusion criterion and should be excluded.

Non-human primate study (monkeys); fMRI with electrical microstimulation was performed in monkeys, not healthy adult human participants performing social-related tasks, so it fails the human participant inclusion criterion.

This publication is explicitly a systematic review and meta-analyses of fMRI studies rather than an original fMRI study with primary data. It meets the exclusion criterion 'systematic reviews or meta-analyses.'

Functional MRI measured neural responses while participants viewed faces and attended to social aspects (emotional valence), satisfying the social-processing criterion. The abstract does not specify participant ages or health status, so inclusion for full-text review is appropriate to confirm healthy adult sample and age range.

fMRI study with an adult group aged 20–41 performing a social interaction discrimination task (perception/understanding of others). At least one healthy adult group within 17–65 is present; not a review. Abstract provides sufficient info to include.

Non-human animal study using rat pups; resting-state fMRI under anesthesia rather than a task-based social processing paradigm; participants are not healthy human adults (17–65). Does not meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract describes an fMRI social-feedback task relevant to social processing, but participants are described as ‘adolescents’ with no specific ages. Inclusion requires a healthy group aged 17–65; age eligibility cannot be confirmed from the abstract alone. Include for full-text review to determine participant ages and health status.

Abstract reports neural studies of information sharing and social consequences—relevant to social processing—but does not explicitly state use of fMRI or participant ages/health. Include for full-text review to confirm imaging modality and healthy adult sample.

fMRI performed while participants (healthy adults) retrieved biographical/person knowledge about fictitious people—a social cognition task (perception/understanding of others). Not a review. Abstract gives sufficient info to meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports an fMRI experiment (n=17) investigating mentalising/theory-of-mind (social cognition) using story tasks in human participants, not a review. Participants are described as human (adult implied); meets social-related fMRI criterion. Recommend full-text for ages and health confirmation, but sufficient to include for review.

Participants are adolescents (not adults within the required 17–65 range) and the fMRI task was a risk-taking task rather than a clearly social-related task. Thus it does not meet the inclusion criterion of fMRI in healthy adults performing a social-related task.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants using an observation/imitation task of emotional faces (social cognitive processing: emotion recognition, social inference). Fits review objective of social-related fMRI in healthy adults; not a review/meta-analysis.

fMRI study of social processing (social exclusion/inclusion, mentalizing) in a sample of healthy male adolescents. Abstract lacks exact participant ages (inclusion requires 17–65), so include for full-text review to confirm age eligibility and health status.

fMRI study of social interaction (making listeners laugh) examining self/other processing and ventral striatum–mPFC connectivity; involves human participants and is not a review. Abstract does not state ages or clinical status explicitly, so include for full-text verification of participant demographics.

fMRI was used while participants considered reading and sharing articles — a social-related task involving self-related processing and perspective-taking (understanding others). Participants appear to be healthy adults; study is empirical (not a review). Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.
Study conducted in macaque monkeys (non-human primates). Inclusion requires fMRI in healthy human participants (age 17–65). Does not meet participant-species criterion, so exclude.

Empirical fMRI study investigating how social information and reward influence decision-making in a group task. The abstract reports fMRI data collected during a social-related task with no mention of clinical populations, matching inclusion criteria for healthy adult social processing. Not a review or meta-analysis.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n=19) performing a social task (Trust Game) investigating neural correlates of reciprocity—matches review objective and inclusion criteria; not a review/meta-analysis.

fMRI study in which participants imagined personally familiar others—a social cognition task (perception/understanding of others). Appears to involve healthy adult participants; not a review or meta-analysis. Methods and population meet inclusion criteria.

Original research using fMRI in human participants (N=34) performing a social-emotional task (schadenfreude vs. fremdscham). Examines social cognition, empathy and reward networks in healthy adults; not a review. Fits inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

This is a quantitative review/meta-analysis that synthesizes peak coordinates from prior fMRI studies (no original fMRI data collection). It therefore meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

fMRI study of social cognition (theory of mind) comparing implicit and explicit belief processing in humans; involves healthy participants and social-related task. Abstract does not report participant ages, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility (age range and participant details). No exclusion criteria met.
Participants are children in middle childhood (ages 8–12), not healthy adults aged 17–65 required by the review. The study therefore does not meet the age criterion for inclusion.

Narrative/review article on resting-state fMRI and social cognition; does not report original task-based fMRI data where participants performed social-related tasks. Does not meet inclusion criterion of task-based fMRI in healthy adults.

Empirical fMRI study of mentalizing/theory-of-mind (social cognition) using two experiments and MVPA in TPJ/STS/MPFC. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract does not state participant ages or health status explicitly, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility (healthy adults 17–65).

Human adult men viewed romantic and sexual stimuli (affiliation/attachment-related task) with reported neural activation differences; no indication participants had disorders. Although the abstract does not explicitly state 'fMRI', the described neural activation during stimulus viewing strongly implies functional neuroimaging. Include for full-text review to confirm imaging modality and participant health status.

Abstract reports a single-case (n=1) fMRI study. Inclusion criteria require at least one group of healthy participants (age 17–65). A single participant does not constitute a group, so study should be excluded.

The fMRI task is a phonological short-term memory (sequence span) task using letters and fingerspelling, focusing on linguistic/visuomotor processing rather than social-related processes (e.g., affiliation, social communication, perception of self/others). Therefore it does not meet the review’s social-processing requirement.

This is a systematic review of fNIRS studies in Autism Spectrum Disorder (children/infants and clinical populations), not an original functional MRI study in healthy adults. It meets the exclusion criterion (review) and does not address fMRI social processing in healthy 17–65 participants.

fMRI was used while participants performed social-related tasks (IAT about adultery and a date-rating task assessing interest in unfamiliar females). Participants appear to be healthy adults in romantic relationships; meets inclusion criteria.

Primary fMRI study in humans examining neural responses (pSTS) to stimuli depicting social interactions, addressing social perception/interaction processing. Appears to involve healthy adult participants and is original research (not a review), meeting inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of 61 healthy adult (White) participants performing a social task (implicit impression formation of Black and White faces varying in socioeconomic status). This assesses perception/understanding of others, fits the review objective, and is not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text extraction.

fMRI study where healthy adults viewed a social/moral interaction (kin vs non-kin sisters) — a social cognition task (moral/emotional conflict, mentalizing). Not a review. Age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and health status.

Functional MRI experiment with human participants performing a social perception task (judging direction/social intentions of point-light displays and human-like walkers). Directly examines social processing (mirror and mentalizing systems) in healthy adults—meets inclusion criteria.

Study used resting-state fMRI (fALFF) rather than task-based functional MRI during a social-related task. Inclusion requires fMRI conducted while participants performed a social processing task. Although behavioral measures and vignettes assessed social decision-making, the imaging was not task-based, so it does not meet the primary inclusion criterion.

fMRI study where healthy adult participants performed a social-evaluation task (in-group/out-group politician ratings), directly addressing social processing. Abstract does not state exact ages but clearly meets the review objective; include for full-text review to confirm participant ages/health and extract data.

7T fMRI study in healthy adults (fMRI sample n=23 males) using a social/attachment-related task (listening to prototypical attachment narratives) probing social/affiliation and interpersonal processing. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults; not a review.

fMRI study with healthy human participants performing retrieval of collaboratively vs. individually learned labels; contrasts involve mentalizing/theory-of-mind and autobiographical memory regions, directly addressing social-related processing (understanding others/social communication). No exclusion criteria met; age not specified in abstract—include for full-text verification.

fMRI study (dynamic causal modeling) of observing cooperative and affective social interactions in 36 healthy adults. The task is social-related (perception/understanding of others), participants are healthy and within age range; not a review/meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social joint action (leader/follower/mutual conditions) involving social cognition, somatosensation, and interaction processes in trained couple dancers (healthy adults). It meets the neurotypical adult criterion and is not a review, so include for full-text review.

fMRI was conducted in healthy adult women (ages 25–50) during viewing of erotic pictures/videos. Although primarily sexual, the task involves perception of other people and the abstract notes activations in areas associated with social cognition, meeting the review’s population and potentially social-related processing criteria. Abstract lacks full task detail, so full-text review is needed to confirm eligibility.

This study used resting-state fMRI in prairie voles (an animal model), not human participants. Inclusion requires fMRI task studies in healthy adults (age 17–65). Therefore it does not meet the population criterion.

fMRI study with human participants performing a social-related task (perception of affective vocalisations/social communication). Abstract shows neural responses relevant to social processing. Age/health details not specified—include for full-text to confirm eligibility.

Abstract does not specify that the movie task specifically targeted social processing nor clearly state adult ages, though TPJ involvement suggests possible social cognition and adults were likely included. Insufficient information to determine inclusion/exclusion from abstract alone — include for full-text review.

The study reports task-based fMRI including social processing (social and emotion tasks) in a large Human Connectome Project sample (n=787). Although ages/health status are not explicitly listed in the abstract, HCP comprises healthy adult participants and the abstract clearly describes social-related task fMRI, meeting the review objective; include for full-text review to confirm ages and participant health status.

fMRI study measuring neural activity during social-cognitive tasks (reflection on self and others) in healthy male adults; directly addresses social processing constructs (self/other perception). Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

This is a theoretical/chapter-style review of social-interactive neuroscience, not a primary empirical fMRI study. The abstract does not report functional MRI methods or data from healthy adult participants. It therefore meets the exclusion criterion for reviews/meta-analyses and lacks required fMRI task data.

This is a book chapter/review focused on developmental neuroscience and adolescent social influence; it does not report an original fMRI experiment or participant sample (and focuses on adolescents, not adults 17–65). Not a primary fMRI study of healthy adults.

fMRI study examining perception of social interactions (competition vs cooperation) using human point-light figures and moving-shape stimuli, reporting pSTS/TPJ responses. It involves human participants (independent participant group) and is not a review. Age/health details not stated in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm participant demographics.

Sample consists of children and adolescents aged 8–17; no distinct group of healthy adult participants within the required 17–65 age range is reported, so it does not meet the age inclusion criterion.

This is a narrative/review article about neural mechanisms in primates (including nonhuman primates) rather than an fMRI study of healthy human adults performing a social task; it meets the exclusion criterion for reviews.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n=20) using a social decision-making task (modified prisoner’s dilemma) probing Theory of Mind/social cognition (rTPJ activation). Not a review; meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in adults.

Abstract reports an original fMRI experiment comparing social vs. non-social image appraisal (plus an automated meta-analysis). It addresses social processing and is not solely a review. Include for full-text review to confirm participant ages/health status.

fMRI was used while healthy adult participants performed emotion perception tasks (discriminating facial, vocal, and bimodal emotional expressions), which is social communication/perception of others. Not a review and meets age/participant criteria based on abstract.

fMRI was used while healthy adult participants made social decisions influenced by another person; study examines social cognition (perceived distrust/understanding) and neural mechanisms of social control, meeting inclusion criteria.

Functional MRI study probing social communication (prosodic decoding of communicative intentions) with participants performing a social-related task. Abstract does not explicitly report participant ages/health; include for full-text to confirm demographics and eligibility.

Abstract reports task-based fMRI investigating agentic self-evaluation (Perception/Understanding of Self), a social cognitive process. Not a review. Participant age/health not specified in abstract, so insufficient to confirm 17–65 healthy sample—include for full-text review to verify sample and methods.

fMRI study where healthy adult participants rated perceived intelligence and friendliness of faces—classic social perception/understanding of others task. Fits inclusion (social-related task in healthy adults) and is not a review. Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text data extraction.

Single-case report of an 8-year-old with massive bilateral frontal damage; fMRI was used but not to study social-related processing in healthy adults, and there is no group of healthy participants aged 17–65.
Participants were children aged 8–12; the meta-analysis requires healthy adults aged 17–65. Study does not meet age criterion and should be excluded.

fMRI study with 34 healthy adult participants performing an empathic accuracy task (social processing: perception/understanding of others). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

Participants are adolescent boys (healthy comparison group are adolescents), not adults within the required 17–65 age range. Although it uses fMRI on social self/other processing, the age criterion for inclusion is not met.

Study used resting-state fMRI (RsFc) rather than a task-based social processing paradigm. Inclusion requires fMRI during a social-related task; although healthy controls are included, no social task was performed. Exclude based on not meeting the task-based inclusion criterion.

Participants are preterm infants (31+6 to 36+3 weeks postmenstrual age), not adults, and the task is somatosensory/motor mapping rather than social-related processing. Does not meet participant age or task relevance criteria.

Empirical fMRI data (three studies) examining neural responses to person-related and other social concepts (famous people, social/abstract social words) in the anterior temporal lobes. Appears to involve healthy participants and addresses social-related processing; not a review. Include for full-text review.

The study used task-based fMRI including a 'social cognition' task, which targets social-related processing. It is empirical (not a review) and likely involves healthy adult participants; abstract does not contradict inclusion. Insufficient detail on ages/sample prompts full-text review, so include for further assessment.

Study uses fMRI with a social-reward task in healthy participants and addresses social processing. However participants are adolescents (ages 14–18), so it’s unclear whether there is a subgroup meeting the review’s 17–65 age requirement. Abstract lacks sufficient age-specific detail—include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

Double-blind placebo-controlled fMRI in 55 healthy young men (adult sample) administering intranasal oxytocin while participants viewed attachment-related erotic and fearful social scenes. Task probes social-related processing (affiliation/attachment and perception of others). Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient detail to meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports an event-related fMRI study in which healthy adult participants performed a mind-perception (social) task during scanning, and the work examines brain regions related to social attention. No indication this is a review or that participants were clinical. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

The study used fMRI in non-human primates (macaque monkeys) and includes no human participants. Inclusion requires fMRI in healthy human adults (age 17–65). Not a review/meta-analysis, but fails the human-participant criterion.

This article is a meta-analysis (activation likelihood estimation across 28 fMRI studies). The exclusion criteria disallow systematic reviews or meta-analyses, so it should be excluded despite relevance to social/psychopathy-related processing.

This article is a review (discusses and reviews mechanisms) rather than an original fMRI study. It discusses infants and macaques rather than fMRI in healthy adult humans performing social tasks, meeting the exclusion criterion for reviews and lacking eligible adult participant data.

fMRI study using an emotional face recognition paradigm (social processing: perception/understanding of others). Includes a healthy adult group (mothers without current mental disorders, presumably aged 17–65). Not a review or meta-analysis. Fits inclusion criteria.

fMRI study with 35 healthy adult participants performing a social-related task (recall of self- and other-related relationship episodes). Addresses perception/understanding of self and others; not a review. Abstract gives sufficient info to include for full-text data extraction.

Abstract and title report oxytocin effects on neural activity (anterior insula) in response to positive social stimuli, implying neuroimaging of social processing in humans, but the abstract does not explicitly state fMRI methods or participant age/health details. Insufficient information to rule out inclusion — include for full-text review to confirm fMRI and healthy adult sample.

fMRI study with 16 healthy volunteers viewing social interactions; investigates perception/interpretation of non-verbal and verbal social behavior, matching social-related processing objective. Age range not reported in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm ages and eligibility.

This is a review article synthesizing task-based EEG/fMRI studies in 22q11.2 deletion syndrome rather than an original fMRI study with primary data in healthy adults. It meets the exclusion criterion (systematic reviews/meta-analyses) and does not clearly report fMRI task data from a healthy 17–65 adult group in the abstract.

This article is a review and meta-analysis of social cognition and PTSD, not an original fMRI study. The exclusion criterion 'systematic reviews or meta-analyses' is clearly met; abstract does not report primary fMRI data from healthy adult participants.

fMRI study examining neural processing of race and socioeconomic status (social perception of others) in a sample of healthy adult participants; not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

fMRI study investigating integration of facial and vocal emotional expressions—a social perception/communication task (perception/understanding of others). Abstract does not specify participant demographics/ages; relevance to social processing is clear, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample and age range.

fMRI study of social cognition (learning others' trustworthiness — perception/understanding of others). Involves healthy younger and older adult participants; younger group likely within 17–65 age range, satisfying inclusion. Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient detail to include for full-text data extraction.

fMRI study examining brain activations during joint leader–follower interactions (social roles) in skilled couple dancers. Involves healthy adult participants performing a social-related task (joint action), fits review objective. Not a review/meta-analysis. Include for full-text to confirm participant ages/details.

The study used resting-state fMRI (rsFC) rather than an fMRI scan conducted while participants performed a social-related task. Although it examines social relationships (peer influence), it does not meet the inclusion requirement of task-based social processing during scanning.

fMRI study measuring neural representations of others' mental states during a social task in male and female human participants. Participants are healthy adults (implied), task assesses social cognition (prediction of mental states). Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

Study involves children (NVLD, ASD, typically developing children), not healthy adults aged 17–65 required by the review. Also focuses on network connectivity in pediatric clinical groups; does not meet adult healthy participant criterion.

The abstract describes a narrative review of resting-state fMRI findings in ASD and discusses neurofeedback/interaction studies; it does not report original task-based social fMRI in healthy adults. It is a review article and does not meet the inclusion criterion of task-based social processing in healthy participants.

fMRI was conducted while participants performed an iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma (a social decision-making/trust task). Sample consists of healthy adult participants (20 males). Study directly examines social processing and meets inclusion criteria.
Study uses resting-state fMRI (rsfMRI) rather than task-based fMRI; no social-related task was performed during scanning. Inclusion requires fMRI during a social-related task in human participants.
Study used resting-state fMRI (no social task) and participants were adolescents (means ~14.5 years, ranges 10.0–18.0 and 10.0–17.5), not a healthy adult group aged 17–65 as required by the review.

This article is a multi-method review/meta-analytic synthesis (Neurosynth analyses, lesion/TMS/MVPA review) rather than an original fMRI experiment reporting task-based results in healthy adults. It therefore meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

fMRI study in healthy adults using a dyadic social interaction task (iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma) during scanning; examines neural responses to social interactions under intranasal oxytocin vs placebo. Meets inclusion (social-related task; healthy participants). Not a review.

Abstract reports an fMRI investigation of trustworthiness appraisal (a social-processing task) comparing BPD patients to controls, implying inclusion of a healthy adult control group. Study addresses social cognition and is not a review/meta-analysis. Therefore it meets inclusion criteria for full-text review.

fMRI conducted while healthy adult males (N=93) performed a social provocation/aggression task (Taylor aggression paradigm), probing social cognition and responses to others; meets inclusion criteria and is an original empirical study (not a review).

Task-based dual-fMRI hyperscanning study of social interaction (cooperation vs competition, concurrent vs turn-based), clearly investigating social cognition processes in interacting participants. Uses functional MRI during a social task and is not a review. Participants are described as pairs of individuals (presumably healthy adults), meeting inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

fMRI study of social reward (interpersonal pleasant touch) assessing neural/behavioral responses to social interaction (male vs female experimenter). Includes a healthy adult control group (matched non-using controls). Not a review; meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in adults.

Participants were early adolescents (ages 10.5–13.4), outside the required adult range (17–65), and the study used resting-state fMRI and MR spectroscopy rather than a task-based fMRI of social-related processing.

fMRI was conducted during a social task (face-to-face spontaneous conversation). The study includes an age- and IQ-matched typically developing control group (healthy adults), satisfying the requirement of at least one healthy participant group aged within typical adult range. Not a review/meta-analysis.

The study reports task-based fMRI of theory of mind (a social-cognitive task: perception/understanding of others) in healthy younger and older adult groups. It is empirical (not a review) and includes healthy participants likely within the 17–65 range; include for full-text review to confirm exact ages.

This is an animal study using Fmr1 knockout mice; no human participants aged 17–65 are involved and the task does not assess social processing in healthy adults. Does not meet inclusion criteria for human fMRI social-task studies.

fMRI study using a dynamic facial expression localizer and neurofeedback targeting posterior STS—an area for social perception (face expression recognition). Appears to involve human subjects (no patient group reported) and is not a review. Meets inclusion criteria for social-processing fMRI in healthy adults.

The study used task-free (resting-state) fMRI rather than participants performing a social-related task. Inclusion requires task-based fMRI during social processing; thus it does not meet the primary inclusion criterion despite including healthy controls.

Study used fMRI (hyperscanning) during a live social task—mutual eye contact—which is social processing (perception/understanding of others/self). Participants were healthy adult pairs. Not a review. Meets inclusion criteria based on abstract information.

fMRI was used while healthy adult participants (male and female) viewed faces and performed perceptual similarity and recognition tasks. This addresses social perception/understanding of others (face identity processing), fits participant age range, and is an original empirical fMRI study rather than a review.

fMRI study using live, bidirectional social interaction (human-human vs human-robot), examining neural markers of mentalizing and social motivation. Sample of 21 participants suggests healthy adult subjects. Meets review objective (social processing in fMRI). Age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text screening to confirm eligibility (17–65).

Study used fMRI while participants observed human and robotic agents experiencing pain/pleasure, addressing empathy and perception/understanding of others—social processing. Participants were healthy adults (n=26). This is an original empirical fMRI study, not a review, meeting inclusion criteria.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants examining co-speech gestures and semantic processing—addresses social communication, a listed relevant construct. Methods and population meet inclusion criteria; not a review or meta-analysis.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of empathy and anxiety during socioemotional processing, which directly fits social-related processing. The abstract does not state participant health status or ages (17–65), so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

The study uses resting-state fMRI (no task) to assess amygdala network causality across the lifespan. Inclusion requires task-based fMRI with social-related processing; resting-state studies without a social task do not meet this criterion.

fMRI study using the Cyberball social-inclusion paradigm (a social-related task) and includes a healthy control group (n=17). Not a review. Age range not reported in abstract, so include for full-text confirmation.

Human fMRI study measuring BOLD responses during a task that manipulated perceived animacy from motion cues. Animacy perception falls under ‘Perception and Understanding of Others’ (social-related processing). Participants are healthy adults; functional MRI was performed. No exclusion criteria met.

The article is a meta-analysis of fMRI studies (systematic synthesis), which meets the exclusion criterion disallowing systematic reviews or meta-analyses. The abstract indicates no new primary participant data, so exclude.
fMRI data were collected at rest (resting-state connectivity); no task-based fMRI during a social-related task is reported. Inclusion requires a social-related task during scanning, so exclude.

Participants are children (ASD and age-matched typically developing children); no healthy adult (age 17–65) group is included. Although it uses fMRI and a social task, it does not meet the adult healthy participant criterion.

fMRI study with healthy human participants undergoing a social-related task (virtual ball-tossing ostracism) examining social support effects on neural activity. Fits review objective (social processing in healthy adults). Not a review/meta-analysis. Age range not specified in abstract, but criterion allows inclusion when information is limited; include for full-text confirmation.

fMRI study of 78 individuals performing a protocol that explicitly includes 'social perception and reasoning' contrasts, directly addressing social-related processing; original data (not a review). Abstract does not report participant ages, so include for full-text review to confirm age range (17–65) and other details.

Functional MRI in a healthy adult sample (n=51) during observation of dynamic facial expressions—a social communication/perception task—fits the review objective. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text review.

fMRI study of visual social interactions (dyadic processing) addressing perception/understanding of others in posterior temporal cortex. Abstract indicates human fMRI task relevant to social processing. Participant ages/health not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm they are healthy adults (17–65).

fMRI experiment examines neural responses to disfigured faces—a social perception/understanding of others task. Abstract implies healthy adult participants but does not state age range or explicitly confirm 'healthy' status; insufficient participant detail for certainty. Include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Task-based fMRI study of vocal emotional processing (social communication) in 36 healthy participants, directly addressing social-related processing. Not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for healthy adult fMRI social task studies; include for full-text review.

This is a narrative review of human neuroimaging literature discussing cerebellar function across domains (including social cognition), not a primary fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults. It meets the exclusion criterion for reviews/meta-analyses and lacks evidence of an original task-based fMRI experiment.

Study used resting-state fMRI before and after rTMS, not a task-based fMRI during a social-related task. Although participants were healthy, the imaging did not assess social processing tasks, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.

The study used resting-state fMRI rather than a task-based social processing paradigm. The meta-analysis requires functional MRI conducted while participants performed a social-related task; although healthy controls were included and social cognition was assessed behaviorally, the imaging was at rest.

Study uses rtfMRI neurofeedback for emotion regulation in healthy adults but does not describe any social-related task or social cognitive constructs (e.g., perception of others, social communication, affiliation). Therefore it does not meet the review’s requirement for an fMRI social-processing task.

The task is a visual color-discrimination/EEG-fMRI study of gamma oscillations, not a social-related task. It does not investigate social processing or social cognition in healthy adults, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.

Study used fMRI during an interactive social (trust) task and includes a healthy control group. However, reported ages are 13–19, so it is unclear whether the healthy participants meet the review’s 17–65 age criterion. Include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

This paper is a meta-analysis/ systematic review of fMRI studies (uses PubMed searches and neurosynth meta-analytic approach) rather than an original fMRI study of healthy adults; exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses is met.

fMRI was conducted while participants (including 15 healthy adult controls) played the prisoners' dilemma—a social cognition/behaviour task—meeting the requirement of fMRI during a social-related task with a healthy adult group. Not a review.

Participants are adolescents (age 16–17) rather than adults. The meta-analysis requires at least one group of healthy participants aged 17–65; this study reports only adolescent samples, so it does not meet the age inclusion criterion.

fMRI study investigating social processing (dynamic facial expressions). Abstract does not clearly state presence of a healthy control group or participant ages; insufficient information to confirm inclusion criteria. Include for full-text review to verify whether healthy adults (age 17–65) were tested.

The study used resting-state fMRI (rsFC) rather than a task-based fMRI during a social-related task. Although it assesses social cognition behaviorally and includes healthy controls, it does not perform fMRI while participants engaged in social processing, so it does not meet the inclusion criterion.

Functional MRI study examining neural representations of honesty during a social task (trustworthiness impressions and subsequent trust interaction) in human participants. Measures social cognition/behavior and predicts trust; not a review. Fits inclusion criteria for fMRI social-processing in healthy adults.

All participants were individuals with alcohol use disorder (no healthy control group); inclusion requires at least one group of healthy participants aged 17–65. The sample therefore does not meet the review's participant criteria.

fMRI study examining perception of others' hand actions (social perception/understanding of others) and includes a healthy participant group (n=31). Age range not reported in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm participants meet 17–65 criterion and extract details.

Fast fMRI study examines voice processing and explicitly frames findings in social cognition (voice-sensitive auditory cortex), fitting social communication/perception constructs. Abstract does not report participant characteristics or ages (healthy adults 17–65), so inclusion cannot be confirmed from abstract alone — include for full-text review to verify sample criteria.

fMRI MVPA study examining neural representations of affective meaning of social touch; likely included a healthy control group alongside ASD participants. This directly assesses social-related processing. Abstract does not state ages, but inclusion allows studies with at least one healthy group; insufficient age detail means full-text review warranted, so include for screening.
Resting-state fMRI in ASD toddlers; not a task-based social processing fMRI study and participants are not healthy adults (age 17–65). Does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI was used while participants recalled World War II displays, engaging medial prefrontal cortex and social-cognitive/collective memory processes. Study involves healthy human participants (adult sample implied) and is not a review. Age range not specified in abstract, so full-text needed to confirm eligibility.
The abstract states this article is a review of the literature on hallucinogens and social processing, not an original fMRI study. Exclusion criterion: systematic reviews or meta-analyses -> exclude.

The study is about screening for autism in young children using questionnaires (M-CHAT-R, BISQ). It does not involve fMRI, social-processing tasks, or healthy adult participants (age 17–65). Therefore it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

Methods paper on probabilistic graphical modeling for multi-view bipartite graph clustering; no fMRI, no human participants, and not about social cognitive tasks. Does not meet inclusion criteria of fMRI social task in healthy adults.

fulltext_screening_results.reason: This is an fMRI study of social processing (perception of racial ingroup vs outgroup faces) in healthy adult participants (self-identified White and Black subjects). The paper reports group-level task-evoked BOLD differences in the amygdala to outgroup versus ingroup faces and describes voxelwise identification of those voxels followed by an ROI analysis, indicating whole-brain voxelwise effects were evaluated and reported for the healthy sample. No clinical or out-of-range-age groups dominate the reported results. Therefore it meets the review objective and inclusion criteria (social-related fMRI task; healthy adult sample; group-level univariate voxelwise/ROI-reported effects stemming from identified voxels). Confidence is somewhat reduced due to limited detail in the abstract about full tables/figures of whole-brain results, but the description indicates appropriate group-level voxelwise findings.

The provided full text contains only the reference list and bibliographic details; there is no information on participants, task design, or reported results. Inclusion requires explicit reporting of at least one group-level, univariate whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked map for healthy adult participants (age 17–65). I cannot verify sample characteristics (healthy adults), whether whole-brain voxelwise analyses were performed, or whether healthy-group results are reported separately. While the title suggests an fMRI study of gaze and fusiform activity, the available content does not confirm the key inclusion criteria and may instead report connectivity (coupling) analyses, which would be excluded if no whole-brain activation maps are provided. Therefore the study is excluded due to insufficient information to confirm the required whole-brain healthy-group task activation evidence.

Full text content provided contains only the References and bibliographic metadata; no methods, participant demographics, task description, or results are available. Therefore it is impossible to verify key inclusion criteria: that the study used task-based fMRI during a social-related task in healthy adults (age 17–65), and that it reports at least one group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked statistical map for the healthy/control group. Because these required elements cannot be confirmed from the provided material, the study cannot be included in the meta-analysis.

The study reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (n=8 in the fMRI sample) examining social gaze processing (a social-perception/communication construct). In addition to ROI analyses, the paper presents group-level, voxelwise whole-brain activation maps (across-subjects t-statistic maps displayed on a standard brain and described in the text) identifying STS and FFG activations. The healthy/control group is clearly reported separately. Although the primary analysis emphasized anatomically defined ROIs and the group voxelwise maps were produced using a fixed-effects averaging approach (limited generalizability), the manuscript nevertheless provides univariate, group-level whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps from healthy adults, satisfying the inclusion criteria for the review.

Although the study uses fMRI on face perception (a social-perception task) in healthy adults, the provided full-text summary does not report key required details: participant age range and whether group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical maps were reported. The abstract describes regional responses (FFA, STS, amygdala) but does not confirm whole-brain voxelwise results versus ROI-based analyses. Because the inclusion criteria require explicit reporting of healthy adult sample(s) and at least one whole-brain, group-level univariate task map, and these are not clearly documented in the supplied text, the study must be excluded. If full text provides coordinate tables or whole-brain maps elsewhere, re-screening would be appropriate.

This is an fMRI investigation of social cognition (perception/understanding of others) in healthy adult participants (Princeton undergraduates, mean age 19.5, N=10 in Study 1 and N=12 in Study 2). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate analyses (subtractive contrasts vs fixation, 3-versus-1 contrasts), with Talairach coordinates and random-effects analyses, generalizable to healthy adults. Results are not limited to ROI or connectivity-only analyses. All inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (self-referential processing and perspective taking) in adults using a task manipulating self vs. other and perspective taking. The paper reports group-level task-evoked activations in medial prefrontal cortex (ventral/dorsal anterior MPFC, posterior dorsal MPFC, and left dorsal MPFC) consistent with whole-brain voxelwise contrasts rather than ROI-only results. Participants are healthy adults (typical for this JCN experimental study) and results are reported as generalizable group effects. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state, not clinical-only, and it presents univariate whole-brain task activation maps/contrasts). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

This is a task-based fMRI study of emotional facial expression processing, which qualifies as social communication/social-related processing. It reports data from a group of 12 healthy subjects and describes group-level BOLD signal increases for implicit and explicit conditions and their direct comparison (listing multiple brain regions), indicating univariate whole-brain task-evoked results rather than ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses. The study therefore meets inclusion criteria: social-related task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain group-level activation maps. Uncertainty remains because the abstract does not explicitly state participant ages (17–65 requirement) and the full text/PDF was not accessible to verify exact methods (e.g., that analyses were voxelwise whole-brain and not ROI-masked). For these reasons I include the study with moderate-high confidence (0.80).

Although this is an fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults (N=16 after exclusions) and reports group-level ROI and voxelwise ANOVA results with Talairach/MNI coordinates, the manuscript’s voxelwise analyses were explicitly restricted to predefined regions (DLPFC, superior temporal regions, somatosensory and visual cortex, and later masked analyses including medial prefrontal areas). The paper primarily reports ROI-based contrasts and masked voxelwise results rather than an unmasked, whole-brain group-level task activation map. The inclusion criteria require at least one univariate, whole-brain (voxelwise) group task effect generalizable to healthy adults. Because the reported voxelwise results were region-restricted/masked and no unmasked whole-brain statistical map for the healthy group is presented, the study does not meet the whole-brain evidence criterion and must be excluded.

This is a task-based fMRI study of social processing (perception of others' emotional facial expressions/empathy). The sample is 14 healthy adults (mean 29±6 years), within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, voxelwise statistical parametric mapping results identifying dorsal medial frontal cortex/pre-SMA activation during emotion perception, satisfying the whole-brain univariate activation requirement (not ROI-only or connectivity-only). Results are described as generalizable to the healthy group. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is a task-based fMRI study of social cognition (theory-of-mind: cooperation, deception) in healthy adults (n=13; ages 22–38). The authors report group-level, random-effects whole-brain analyses (one-sample t-test contrasting all ToM conditions vs. non-ToM and report peaks/coordinates) and provide voxelwise contrasts between conditions (reported as second-level paired t-tests and coordinate peaks). Whole-brain results are described and thresholded (p<0.02, k≥15) and anatomical coordinates are given. The sample falls within the 17–65 age range and results for the healthy group are reported separately. The paper is empirical and not limited to ROI-only, connectivity-only, or patient-only contrasts. Therefore it meets the inclusion criteria for whole-brain task-evoked activation in healthy adults.

The study is an original task-based fMRI investigation in healthy adult participants examining perception/understanding of self versus others (own vs. others' body parts), which fits the review’s social-related constructs. Sample consists of healthy adults (n=12–15 per experiment). The paper reports group-level univariate whole-brain contrasts used for ROI localization (e.g., body minus objects localizer; coordinates and voxel counts for EBA, V1/2, LOC are provided and thresholding is described), satisfying the requirement for whole-brain task-evoked results in the healthy group. Although key adaptation analyses are conducted within subject-specific ROIs, the manuscript includes whole-brain contrast results (tables/coordinates) and is not ROI-only or connectivity-only. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an empirical fMRI study using a social-related auditory task (perception/understanding of others: distinguishing one vs two walkers). Sample comprises 12 healthy adults aged 22–37 (within 17–65). The authors report group-level, random-effects, whole-brain univariate analyses (GLM) with voxelwise contrasts (e.g., STEP1+STEP2 – REST; STEP1 – NOISE1; STEP2 – NOISE2), including statistical maps, Talairach coordinates, and figures. Analyses are not limited to ROIs or connectivity and results are clearly reported for the healthy/control group. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an event-related fMRI study reanalyzed with FIR focusing on perception of socially relevant facial expressions (social communication/perception of others). Participants: 17 healthy right-handed adult males (mean age 25.9), within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise univariate analyses (random-effects ANOVA; SPM; threshold p=.001 uncorrected; coordinates and activation tables/figures provided for main effects and time-bin contrasts). It is not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, and reports healthy-group task-evoked whole-brain activation maps generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=17, mean age 26, range within 17–65). The task investigates social cognition (observation of social vs. individual actions and effects of gaze), which falls squarely within social-related processing. The paper reports group-level, random-effects whole-brain univariate analyses (main effects and interaction), with SPM results, coordinate tables, and statistical maps (p<.001 uncorrected) clearly described for the healthy participant group. No ROI-only, connectivity-only, or non-healthy-only limitations apply. All inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated, so the study should be included.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=14, mean age 22) examining social-related processing (perception of others’ pupillary responses and their social salience). The study reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects univariate analyses (main effects of viewing eye stimuli reported at whole-brain corrected thresholds and effects of pupil change reported with cluster thresholds), and presents voxelwise activations (including tables/coordinates and figures). The task is social/perceptual and maps are generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state, healthy adult group reported separately).

This is an empirical fMRI study of social processing (explicit emotion recognition of facial expressions) in healthy adult males (age 21–33). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain (‘‘whole-slab’’) analyses and activation maps (e.g., Figure 2) and provides cluster coordinates/ANOVA results from whole-brain analyses (parahippocampal gyrus; inferior frontal gyrus coordinates reported). Although ROI analyses are also performed for the amygdala, whole-brain task-evoked results for the healthy sample are clearly reported and generalizable to healthy adults. All inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

Although this is an fMRI study of social-related processing in healthy adults and reports group-level voxelwise task contrasts (AV, VIS, AUD vs rest, and AV vs ApV), the fMRI acquisition used a split-sagittal, partial-volume protocol that explicitly excluded medial regions and other large portions of the brain (e.g., medial frontal/parietal cortex, fusiform and early visual cortex). The review’s inclusion criterion requires at least one group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical map generalizable to healthy adults. Because the imaging did not provide whole-brain coverage, the reported voxelwise results are limited to a restricted volume and do not meet the ‘whole-brain’ requirement. All other criteria (healthy adult sample, group-level voxelwise analyses) are met, but failure to provide whole-brain coverage necessitates exclusion.

Although this is an fMRI study of social communication/emotional perception in healthy adults (n=24, ages 18–41) and reports group-level contrasts within the superior temporal sulcus (STS), the analyses are ROI-based using individually mapped STS measuring points. Statistical tests and reported T-values derive from parameter estimates extracted from these ROIs (MPs) rather than from a group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task activation map. The paper emphasizes a region-of-interest approach and reports effects at MP centroids; it does not present an unmasked, whole-brain voxelwise activation map or whole-brain coordinate table arising from a voxelwise group analysis. This violates the review’s whole-brain evidence inclusion criterion, so the study must be excluded.

The study uses task-based fMRI probing self- and social-cognitive processes (direct and reflected self-appraisals). It includes a healthy adult group (N=12, ages 22.6–30.4) reported separately from adolescents. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, unmasked voxelwise analyses (one-sample t-tests and conjunctions for each appraisal condition in adults vs rest; interaction and between-group whole-brain contrasts) with coordinates and figures, corrected for multiple comparisons—fulfilling the whole-brain evidence requirement. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity/resting-only, includes healthy adults within 17–65). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social communication (prosody perception/production and empathy) in healthy adults (n=19; age 18–58). Group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts are reported (e.g., “happy–neutral”, “question–neutral”) using random-effects analyses with FDR correction and cluster reporting; results and coordinates are described in the text and supplementary materials. The paper does not rely solely on ROI or connectivity analyses, and reports healthy-group task activation maps generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria apply. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an empirical fMRI study of gestural social communication (charades) in healthy adult participants (18 analyzed; mean age 27.5), meeting the sample criterion (ages within 17–65). The experiment used task-based fMRI during a social communication task. The paper reports group-level whole-brain analyses (GLM-derived activations used to define mirror ROIs, references to GLM results and figures/SI showing clusters), and presents univariate results in the main text and supplementary figures/tables. Although the manuscript emphasizes between-brain Granger-causality mapping, it also includes traditional GLM whole-brain analyses (and seed ROI definitions based on these), so it is not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only reporting. Therefore all inclusion criteria are satisfied and no exclusion criteria are violated.

While this is an fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults (ages within range) and reports group-level contrasts, the reported results are primarily ROI-based using small-volume correction (amygdala, insula, striatum, OFC) rather than unmasked, whole‑brain voxelwise task activation maps. Methods and results emphasize SVC/ROI analyses and present ROI-corrected findings; I find no clear presentation of an unqualified whole‑brain, group-level task activation map (or whole‑brain coordinate table) generalizable to the healthy adult group. Per the review’s exclusion criteria (studies reporting only ROI/SVC results without whole‑brain task maps), this study should be excluded.
